content.justification: Lists common start dates for software warranties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be aware of these options and negotiate the most favorable start date.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can propose various start dates for software warranties.
content.source_insight: The choice of start date significantly impacts the effective warranty period.
content.text: The software warranty may start to run from date of activation, customer acceptance or date of delivery to Zebracorp, or such other mutually agreed point in time.

content.verbatim_text: As with hardware warranty, it is important to make sure that the duration of the warranty is back-to-back with our end customer commitments whenever we agree that warranty starts already when the software is delivered to ZEBRACORP.
content.plain_text: As with hardware, ensure software warranty duration is back-to-back with end-customer commitments, especially if it starts upon delivery to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical principle for Zebracorp to avoid a warranty gap and ensure it can meet its own customer obligations. It mirrors the hardware warranty strategy.
content.justification: Emphasizes the importance of aligning software warranty periods with end-customer commitments.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its supplier warranties cover its obligations to its own customers, particularly regarding start dates.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to require back-to-back warranty durations to cover its end-customer commitments.
content.source_insight: Reinforces the 'back-to-back' principle across different product types.
content.text: As with hardware warranty, it is important to make sure that the duration of the warranty is back-to-back with our end customer commitments whenever we agree that warranty starts already when the software is delivered to ZEBRACORP.

content.verbatim_text: In the event the licensor is reluctant to agree to tie the start of the warranty to our end customer acceptance or date of activation, we may need to adjust the duration of warranty period where necessary so that end customer can avail itself to certain minimum warranty term.
content.plain_text: If a licensor won't tie warranty start to end-customer acceptance/activation, Zebracorp may need to extend the warranty duration to ensure the end customer gets a minimum term.
content.expert_insight: This is a practical adjustment to ensure the end customer is still covered, even if the ideal warranty start date cannot be achieved. It prioritizes end-customer satisfaction.
content.justification: Offers a strategy for adjusting warranty duration if the ideal start date cannot be secured.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp may need to extend warranty periods to compensate for an earlier start date, ensuring its end customers receive adequate coverage.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may face requests to extend warranty duration if they insist on an earlier start date for the warranty.
content.source_insight: This is a flexible approach to meet end-customer expectations despite supplier resistance on start dates.
content.text: In the event the licensor is reluctant to agree to tie the start of the warranty to our end customer acceptance or date of activation, we may need to adjust the duration of warranty period where necessary so that end customer can avail itself to certain minimum warranty term.

content.verbatim_text: Note that we should be careful to accept any verbiage, which says that the warranty starts from the first date of delivery/installation since this addition may imply that the software warranty only applies to the initial first delivery of the software and not to any subsequent deliveries.
content.plain_text: Be careful accepting language that states warranty starts from the 'first date of delivery/installation,' as it may imply coverage only for the initial delivery, not subsequent ones.
content.expert_insight: This is a subtle but critical point. Zebracorp must ensure comprehensive coverage for all software deployments, not just the initial one, to avoid significant gaps in protection.
content.justification: Warns against specific problematic language for warranty start dates that could limit coverage.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must scrutinize warranty start date language to ensure it covers all software deliveries, not just the first.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that Zebracorp will challenge language that limits warranty coverage to initial deliveries.
content.source_insight: This addresses a potential loophole that could significantly reduce Zebracorp's protection.
content.text: Note that we should be careful to accept any verbiage, which says that the warranty starts from the first date of delivery/installation since this addition may imply that the software warranty only applies to the initial first delivery of the software and not to any subsequent deliveries.

content.verbatim_text: The typical duration for a software warranty ranges from ninety days to twelve months. Zebracorp standard warranty offering to its end customers typically extends to ninety days. However, it is by no means unusual for us to be committed to software warranties that exceed ninety days. In many countries where we operate it may not be uncommon to see software warranties of up to twelve months, or even longer. Such warranties are fairly prevalent in particular in the European countries as opposed to the US market where the software warranties are as a rule limited to ninety days or six months.
content.plain_text: Typical software warranties range from 90 days to 12 months, with Zebracorp's end-customer offerings usually 90 days. Longer warranties (up to 12 months or more) are common in Europe, while the US market typically limits them to 90 days or six months.
content.expert_insight: This provides crucial market intelligence. Zebracorp must be aware of regional differences and its own customer commitments to negotiate appropriate software warranty durations.
content.justification: Provides context on typical software warranty durations and regional differences.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should tailor its software warranty requests based on regional norms and its own end-customer commitments.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware of varying software warranty expectations based on geographic market and Zebracorp's customer obligations.
content.source_insight: Highlights the impact of geography on warranty expectations.
content.text: The typical duration for a software warranty ranges from ninety days to twelve months. Zebracorp standard warranty offering to its end customers typically extends to ninety days. However, it is by no means unusual for us to be committed to software warranties that exceed ninety days. In many countries where we operate it may not be uncommon to see software warranties of up to twelve months, or even longer. Such warranties are fairly prevalent in particular in the European countries as opposed to the US market where the software warranties are as a rule limited to ninety days or six months.

content.verbatim_text: Note however at the antivirus warranty does not necessarily need to apply over an extended period of time but it may be sufficient that the warranty applies only on the software at the time of delivery.
content.plain_text: Antivirus warranties don't necessarily need to be extended; it may be sufficient for them to apply only at the time of software delivery.
content.expert_insight: This is a pragmatic approach. Antivirus protection is often an ongoing service, so a 'point-in-time' warranty at delivery for the software itself can be acceptable.
content.justification: Provides flexibility for the duration of antivirus warranties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept antivirus warranties that are limited to the time of software delivery.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may find Zebracorp amenable to limited-duration antivirus warranties.
content.source_insight: Recognizes that ongoing security is often handled by separate services, not static warranties.
content.text: Note however at the antivirus warranty does not necessarily need to apply over an extended period of time but it may be sufficient that the warranty applies only on the software at the time of delivery.

content.verbatim_text: Sophisticated vendors may seek to exclude their liability for warranty failures in certain circumstances, where the failure is caused by acts or omissions of Zebracorp or the end user of the product, or for damage that occurs outside what would be the ordinary or expected use for the product. The supplier may as an example request the following exclusions: Misuse, abuse or improper use; Operation beyond specifications or external factors such as temperature, humidity, corrosive elements; Use in combination with products not supplier by the vendor; Improper installation; Lack of proper maintenance; and - Repair by other than the vendor.
content.plain_text: Vendors often seek warranty exclusions for failures caused by Zebracorp/end-user acts or use outside ordinary expectations, such as misuse, operation beyond specs, third-party combinations, improper installation, lack of maintenance, or third-party repairs.
content.expert_insight: This lists common risk-shifting exclusions. Zebracorp must be familiar with these to effectively negotiate and limit their scope, ensuring the warranty remains meaningful.
content.justification: Describes common warranty exclusions sought by vendors and provides examples.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should anticipate these exclusions and be prepared to negotiate their terms carefully.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers commonly propose these exclusions to limit their liability for issues outside their control.
content.source_insight: These are standard defensive clauses for suppliers.
content.text: Sophisticated vendors may seek to exclude their liability for warranty failures in certain circumstances, where the failure is caused by acts or omissions of Zebracorp or the end user of the product, or for damage that occurs outside what would be the ordinary or expected use for the product. The supplier may as an example request the following exclusions: Misuse, abuse or improper use; Operation beyond specifications or external factors such as temperature, humidity, corrosive elements; Use in combination with products not supplier by the vendor; Improper installation; Lack of proper maintenance; and - Repair by other than the vendor.

content.verbatim_text: Some exclusions can be so broad that almost anything will negate the warranty, and care should be taken when agreeing to these. Each exclusion should be capable of being objectively measured, and we should not accept any of the above exclusions without careful consideration on a case-by-case basis.
content.plain_text: Be cautious with broad exclusions; each must be objectively measurable, and none should be accepted without careful, case-by-case consideration.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical instruction. Overly broad or subjective exclusions can render a warranty meaningless. Zebracorp must insist on clear, objective criteria.
content.justification: Provides a general warning and a rule for evaluating warranty exclusions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must rigorously review all exclusions, ensuring they are specific, objective, and reasonable.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to scrutinize exclusions for clarity and objectivity.
content.source_insight: This is a fundamental principle of contract drafting to avoid ambiguity and unfairness.
content.text: Some exclusions can be so broad that almost anything will negate the warranty, and care should be taken when agreeing to these. Each exclusion should be capable of being objectively measured, and we should not accept any of the above exclusions without careful consideration on a case-by-case basis.

content.verbatim_text: Also failure of the product to meet the warranty has to be solely due to such excluded event or circumstance.
content.plain_text: For an exclusion to apply, the product's warranty failure must be *solely* due to the excluded event or circumstance.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial legal principle. It prevents suppliers from using minor contributing factors as an excuse to void a warranty. Zebracorp must insist on this 'sole causation' requirement.
content.justification: Specifies a crucial condition for exclusions to apply, preventing arbitrary warranty denials.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should insist on the 'solely due to' causation for any exclusion to be valid.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that Zebracorp will push for strict causation requirements for exclusions.
content.source_insight: This protects Zebracorp from suppliers attempting to escape liability based on partial causation.
content.text: Also failure of the product to meet the warranty has to be solely due to such excluded event or circumstance.

content.verbatim_text: The exclusion of misuse or abuse is generally acceptable. However the term improper use can subjective and we should be careful to accept that exclusion. As long as the product is used in accordance and in compIiance with the specifications, the use should not be improper. Instead of excluding ‘improper use’ we should exclude use outside the product specifications.
content.plain_text: While 'misuse or abuse' exclusions are acceptable, 'improper use' is subjective; Zebracorp should instead exclude 'use outside the product specifications' for clarity.
content.expert_insight: This is a smart negotiation point. Replacing a subjective term ('improper use') with an objective, measurable standard ('use outside product specifications') protects Zebracorp from arbitrary warranty denials.
content.justification: Provides specific guidance on negotiating 'improper use' exclusions to ensure objectivity.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should clarify 'improper use' to mean 'use outside product specifications' to avoid subjective interpretations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to seek a more objective definition for 'improper use' exclusions.
content.source_insight: Focuses on objective, verifiable criteria for warranty exclusions.
content.text: The exclusion of misuse or abuse is generally acceptable. However the term improper use can subjective and we should be careful to accept that exclusion. As long as the product is used in accordance and in compIiance with the specifications, the use should not be improper. Instead of excluding ‘improper use’ we should exclude use outside the product specifications.

content.verbatim_text: The same applies to requests to exclude failures caused by operation of the products beyond their capabilities. The operating parameters should be spelled out in the product specification, and should we, or our end customer, fail to observe those, then and only then it is reasonable that the supplier of the product is excused from its warranty obligations.
content.plain_text: Exclusions for operation beyond capabilities should be tied to clearly defined operating parameters in product specifications; only then is it reasonable for the supplier to be excused.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces the need for clear, documented standards. If the limits are explicit, Zebracorp understands its responsibilities, and the supplier's exclusion becomes fair.
content.justification: Extends the principle of objective measurement to 'operation beyond capabilities' exclusions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure that any 'operation beyond capabilities' exclusions are linked to clearly defined and documented operating parameters.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must clearly define operating parameters in product specifications if they wish to use this as a valid exclusion.
content.source_insight: Emphasizes the importance of clear documentation for defining operational boundaries.
content.text: The same applies to requests to exclude failures caused by operation of the products beyond their capabilities. The operating parameters should be spelled out in the product specification, and should we, or our end customer, fail to observe those, then and only then it is reasonable that the supplier of the product is excused from its warranty obligations.

content.verbatim_text: Excluding supplier’s warranty to use of product in combination with other products is not acceptable as such. We do use our suppliers’ products in conjunction with our own or third party products and equipment. If we were to agree to this exclusion, we should specify that the combination itself must cause the failure in the product, and the combination must not have been known to the supplier or recommended or otherwise permitted by the supplier.
content.plain_text: Excluding warranties for use with other products is generally unacceptable. If agreed, specify the combination *must* cause the failure and be unknown/unpermitted by the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical point for Zebracorp, whose business often involves integrating various components. A blanket exclusion would severely limit product utility. The compromise ensures fair application.
content.justification: Provides a strong stance against a common exclusion and offers a compromise if necessary.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should strongly resist blanket exclusions for use with other products and, if forced, narrow them significantly.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' blanket exclusions for use with other products will be challenged; they should be prepared to narrow them to specific, unknown, and unpermitted combinations that cause failure.
content.source_insight: This protects Zebracorp's ability to integrate products into its broader systems.
content.text: Excluding supplier’s warranty to use of product in combination with other products is not acceptable as such. We do use our suppliers’ products in conjunction with our own or third party products and equipment. If we were to agree to this exclusion, we should specify that the combination itself must cause the failure in the product, and the combination must not have been known to the supplier or recommended or otherwise permitted by the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: The lack of proper maintenance can also be difficult to measure objectively. When agreeing to such exclusion we should verify how proper maintenance is specified in the product specification and product documentation, and whether such maintenance recommendations are reasonable taken into account the nature and planned use of the products/equipment.
content.plain_text: 'Lack of proper maintenance' exclusions require verifying that maintenance is objectively specified in documentation and reasonable for the product's use.
content.expert_insight: This ensures that the burden of 'proper maintenance' is clearly defined and fair, preventing arbitrary warranty denials based on vague maintenance requirements.
content.justification: Provides guidance on negotiating 'lack of proper maintenance' exclusions to ensure objectivity.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure that 'proper maintenance' is clearly defined and reasonable before accepting this exclusion.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must clearly document their maintenance requirements and ensure they are reasonable if they wish to use this exclusion.
content.source_insight: Emphasizes the need for clear, documented standards for maintenance.
content.text: The lack of proper maintenance can also be difficult to measure objectively. When agreeing to such exclusion we should verify how proper maintenance is specified in the product specification and product documentation, and whether such maintenance recommendations are reasonable taken into account the nature and planned use of the products/equipment.

content.verbatim_text: Improper installation can be usually accepted as a warranty exclusion provided that the installation is done performed by the supplier or any third party authorized by it.
content.plain_text: 'Improper installation' can be an acceptable warranty exclusion if the installation is performed by the supplier or its authorized third party.
content.expert_insight: This is a logical concession. If the supplier (or its authorized agent) controls the installation, they should be responsible for its quality. If Zebracorp installs, the exclusion is fair.
content.justification: Defines an acceptable condition for 'improper installation' exclusion.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept this exclusion if the installation is performed by the supplier or its authorized party.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can expect Zebracorp to accept 'improper installation' exclusions if they or their authorized parties perform the installation.
content.source_insight: Aligns responsibility with control over the installation process.
content.text: Improper installation can be usually accepted as a warranty exclusion provided that the installation is done performed by the supplier or any third party authorized by it.

content.verbatim_text: In each of the above cases, we should specify that the misuse, unauthorized combination etc. was the actual cause of the product failing to meet the warranty.
content.plain_text: For all exclusions (misuse, unauthorized combination, etc.), Zebracorp should specify that the excluded event was the *actual cause* of the product's warranty failure.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces the 'sole causation' principle across all exclusions, preventing suppliers from using minor issues to escape liability for genuine defects.
content.justification: Reinforces the 'causation' requirement for all exclusions to apply.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must insist on clear proof that the excluded event directly caused the warranty failure.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that Zebracorp will require clear and direct causation for any exclusion to be valid.
content.source_insight: A crucial legal principle to ensure fairness in warranty claims.
content.text: In each of the above cases, we should specify that the misuse, unauthorized combination etc. was the actual cause of the product failing to meet the warranty.

content.verbatim_text: Repair by others should not automatically void a warranty. Zebracorp or our customers may routinely use third party repair shops or elect to do self-maintenance.
content.plain_text: 'Repair by others' should not automatically void a warranty, as Zebracorp and its customers may use third-party repair or self-maintenance.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical point for large organizations like Zebracorp that need flexibility in maintenance. A blanket 'repair by others' exclusion is impractical and should be resisted.
content.justification: Provides a strong stance against a common, restrictive exclusion.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should resist exclusions that automatically void warranties due to third-party repairs or self-maintenance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect resistance to 'repair by others' voiding warranties from Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: This protects Zebracorp's operational flexibility and cost management.
content.text: Repair by others should not automatically void a warranty. Zebracorp or our customers may routinely use third party repair shops or elect to do self-maintenance.

content.verbatim_text: In addition, some vendors seek to exclude warranty in case Zebracorp’s tests have failed to detect a defect. This type of exclusion should be generally rejected. Zebracorp does not test the product against any and all requirement specification requirements and even if we did, not all the faults appear in the testing but only after a while in use. The very idea with warranty is to provide the purchasing party with the right to return products that experience defects after their installation and initial testing.
content.plain_text: Exclusions for Zebracorp's failure to detect defects should generally be rejected, as warranties cover defects appearing after installation and initial testing, which Zebracorp cannot fully anticipate.
content.expert_insight: This exclusion fundamentally undermines the purpose of a warranty, which is to cover latent defects. Zebracorp must strongly reject this, as it shifts an unreasonable burden onto the buyer.
content.justification: Provides a strong argument for rejecting 'failure to detect defect' exclusions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should strongly reject any exclusion based on its own failure to detect defects during testing.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect rejection of exclusions based on Zebracorp's testing limitations.
content.source_insight: This defends the core purpose of a warranty: protection against post-delivery/testing failures.
content.text: In addition, some vendors seek to exclude warranty in case Zebracorp’s tests have failed to detect a defect. This type of exclusion should be generally rejected. Zebracorp does not test the product against any and all requirement specification requirements and even if we did, not all the faults appear in the testing but only after a while in use. The very idea with warranty is to provide the purchasing party with the right to return products that experience defects after their installation and initial testing.

content.verbatim_text: Services warranties i.e. warranties in relation to the performance of service have often more limited practical relevance as compared to product warranties. This is predominantly due to the fact that most services are in any event subject to acceptance, while ongoing services such as in e.g. maintenance and support are subject to service level agreements and KPIs.
content.plain_text: Service warranties have limited practical relevance compared to product warranties because most services are subject to acceptance, and ongoing services use SLAs and KPIs.
content.expert_insight: This explains why service warranties are often less critical than product warranties. Zebracorp should focus on robust acceptance criteria and SLAs for services, which provide more immediate and measurable control.
content.justification: Explains the context and reduced relevance of service warranties compared to product warranties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should understand that other contractual mechanisms (acceptance, SLAs) often provide stronger protection for services than standalone warranties.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should understand that service warranties are often less contentious due to the presence of other performance monitoring tools.
content.source_insight: Distinguishes between the nature of product and service guarantees.
content.text: Services warranties i.e. warranties in relation to the performance of service have often more limited practical relevance as compared to product warranties. This is predominantly due to the fact that most services are in any event subject to acceptance, while ongoing services such as in e.g. maintenance and support are subject to service level agreements and KPIs.

content.verbatim_text: The service warranty that provides that the services are rendered in professional and skilful manner is a minimum requirement and should be non-contentious.
content.plain_text: A service warranty for professional and skillful performance is a minimum, non-contentious requirement.
content.expert_insight: This is a basic expectation for any professional service. Zebracorp should always include this and expect no resistance.
content.justification: Defines a minimum, non-contentious service warranty requirement.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should always insist on a warranty for professional and skillful service delivery.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect to provide a warranty for professional and skillful service, as it's a basic expectation.
content.source_insight: This is a fundamental standard for service quality.
content.text: The service warranty that provides that the services are rendered in professional and skilful manner is a minimum requirement and should be non-contentious.

content.verbatim_text: In contrast to a product warranty, it is not uncommon to have a service warranty with no defined warranty period. Whenever a specific warranty period is defined, the warranty should start to run from the date of acceptance. The duration of the warranty period should be sufficient to enable us to verify the results of the service and to have any deficiencies rectified.
content.plain_text: Unlike product warranties, service warranties often lack a defined period; if defined, it should start from acceptance and be long enough to verify results and rectify deficiencies.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the practical focus for service warranties. The period should be tied to the ability to assess and correct the service, rather than a fixed product lifespan.
content.justification: Describes common practices for service warranty periods and Zebracorp's requirements.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure that any defined service warranty period starts from acceptance and is adequate for verification and rectification.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that if a service warranty period is defined, Zebracorp will want it to start from acceptance and be sufficient for evaluation.
content.source_insight: Emphasizes the functional purpose of the warranty period for services.
content.text: In contrast to a product warranty, it is not uncommon to have a service warranty with no defined warranty period. Whenever a specific warranty period is defined, the warranty should start to run from the date of acceptance. The duration of the warranty period should be sufficient to enable us to verify the results of the service and to have any deficiencies rectified.

content.verbatim_text: The time frames used in our contract templates are examples only and should be modified on case-by-case basis.
content.plain_text: Timeframes in Zebracorp's contract templates are examples only and should be modified case-by-case.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial internal instruction. It emphasizes flexibility and the need for customization, preventing rigid adherence to potentially unsuitable template terms.
content.justification: Emphasizes flexibility for template timeframes, requiring case-by-case modification.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp personnel must adapt template timeframes to specific contract needs.
content.implication_supplier: N/A (internal instruction).
content.source_insight: Highlights the dynamic nature of contract terms and the need for customization.
content.text: The time frames used in our contract templates are examples only and should be modified on case-by-case basis.

content.verbatim_text: The remedy for failure to meet a service warranty is typically the re-performance of the respective service. Most Zebracorp procurement contract templates do not specify such remedies, but having these remedies specified is generally not problematic.
content.plain_text: The typical remedy for service warranty failure is re-performance; while Zebracorp templates often don't specify this, it's generally not problematic to do so.
content.expert_insight: Re-performance is the most logical and common remedy for service failures. Zebracorp should consider explicitly stating this for clarity, as it's usually non-contentious.
content.justification: Describes the typical remedy for service warranties and Zebracorp's stance on specifying it.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can expect re-performance as the remedy and can explicitly include this in contracts for clarity.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers typically offer re-performance as a remedy, and Zebracorp is open to specifying this.
content.source_insight: This is a practical and common-sense approach to service remedies.
content.text: The remedy for failure to meet a service warranty is typically the re-performance of the respective service. Most Zebracorp procurement contract templates do not specify such remedies, but having these remedies specified is generally not problematic.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that whenever the services are of advisory nature, it is generally acceptable to state that ‘no specific business result is warranted or guaranteed’.
content.plain_text: For advisory services, it's generally acceptable to state that 'no specific business result is warranted or guaranteed.'
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial distinction for advisory services, where outcomes are influenced by many factors beyond the advisor's control. Zebracorp should accept this limitation.
content.justification: Provides guidance on a specific type of service warranty for advisory services.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should accept disclaimers for specific business results when procuring advisory services.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers of advisory services can expect Zebracorp to accept disclaimers regarding specific business outcomes.
content.source_insight: Acknowledges the inherent uncertainty in advisory outcomes.
content.text: Please note that whenever the services are of advisory nature, it is generally acceptable to state that ‘no specific business result is warranted or guaranteed’.

content.verbatim_text: Certain warranties such as in e.g. warranties for certain product attributes, backward or forward compatibility and interoperability are often referred to as non-standard warranties as they go beyond the typical warranties against products defects and non-functionality.
content.plain_text: Warranties for product attributes, compatibility, and interoperability are considered non-standard, as they exceed typical defect and non-functionality warranties.
content.expert_insight: This categorizes specific types of warranties that often require more negotiation and strategic consideration due to their broader scope.
content.justification: Defines and provides examples of non-standard warranties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should recognize these as non-standard and understand they may require more negotiation.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that these are considered non-standard warranties and may be subject to more scrutiny.
content.source_insight: Helps in classifying and prioritizing different warranty types.
content.text: Certain warranties such as in e.g. warranties for certain product attributes, backward or forward compatibility and interoperability are often referred to as non-standard warranties as they go beyond the typical warranties against products defects and non-functionality.

content.verbatim_text: These non-standard warranties can often be negotiated away, and they can prove mandatory only in cases where such warranties are specifically required by Zebracorp’s end customers, or where we have specific requirements for a particular product or deliverable.
content.plain_text: Non-standard warranties can often be negotiated away, becoming mandatory only if required by Zebracorp's end customers or for specific product needs.
content.expert_insight: This provides a clear strategy: prioritize non-standard warranties only when there's a direct business need or flow-down requirement, otherwise, they are negotiable concessions.
content.justification: Provides guidance on the negotiability and necessity of non-standard warranties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should only insist on non-standard warranties when there's a clear business or customer mandate.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can often negotiate away non-standard warranties unless Zebracorp has specific, compelling reasons to retain them.
content.source_insight: Sets a clear priority for when to insist on these more complex warranties.
content.text: These non-standard warranties can often be negotiated away, and they can prove mandatory only in cases where such warranties are specifically required by Zebracorp’s end customers, or where we have specific requirements for a particular product or deliverable.

content.verbatim_text: It is advisable to speak to a member of the L&C team, or the respective Product Line or Customer Team before agreeing to remove such warranties.
content.plain_text: Consult the L&C team, Product Line, or Customer Team before agreeing to remove non-standard warranties.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical internal instruction. It ensures proper internal alignment and risk assessment before making concessions on potentially important non-standard warranties.
content.justification: Provides an internal process step for removing non-standard warranties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp personnel must seek internal consultation before making concessions on non-standard warranties.
content.implication_supplier: N/A (internal instruction).
content.source_insight: Ensures that decisions on non-standard warranties are made with full organizational awareness.
content.text: It is advisable to speak to a member of the L&C team, or the respective Product Line or Customer Team before agreeing to remove such warranties.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp may also request “warranties” for non-product matters. For example, we might request that the seller “warrant” that it complies with all applicable laws or that the seller is authorized to execute the agreement.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may request 'warranties' for non-product matters, such as compliance with laws or the seller's authority to execute the agreement.
content.expert_insight: These are fundamental representations and covenants, often mislabeled as 'warranties' in common parlance. They are crucial for legal and operational assurance.
content.justification: Describes and provides examples of non-product warranties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp seeks these assurances to ensure legal compliance and proper contractual authority.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to request these fundamental assurances.
content.source_insight: These are essential for establishing the legal validity and compliance of the contract and the supplier.
content.text: Zebracorp may also request “warranties” for non-product matters. For example, we might request that the seller “warrant” that it complies with all applicable laws or that the seller is authorized to execute the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Where requested by the seller, we should be able change the word “warrants” to in e.g. “covenants” or “shall ensure”. Most jurisdictions will not make a significant difference between a warranty and such other covenant. The key for Zebracorp is that the wording provides a binding commitment on the supplier or the persons representing the supplier.
content.plain_text: If requested by the seller, Zebracorp can change 'warrants' to 'covenants' or 'shall ensure' for non-product matters, as long as the wording provides a binding commitment.
content.expert_insight: This is a flexible negotiation tactic. It focuses on the legal effect (binding commitment) rather than the specific term, allowing for concessions on wording without sacrificing substance.
content.justification: Offers a linguistic compromise for non-product 'warranties' and explains the underlying principle.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can be flexible on the specific term used, provided the supplier's commitment remains legally binding.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may find Zebracorp amenable to changing 'warrants' to 'covenants' or 'shall ensure' for non-product matters.
content.source_insight: Prioritizes legal enforceability over specific terminology.
content.text: Where requested by the seller, we should be able change the word “warrants” to in e.g. “covenants” or “shall ensure”. Most jurisdictions will not make a significant difference between a warranty and such other covenant. The key for Zebracorp is that the wording provides a binding commitment on the supplier or the persons representing the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: It is customary for a vendor to include a provisions stating that the warranties they have provided in the agreement are exclusive i.e. the only and sole warranties given in respect of the sold deliverables. A typical clause would read in e.g. as follows: “The warranties and remedies contained in this [Agreement] are the exclusive warranties and remedies given by the [Seller] and are in lieu of and specifically exclude all other express, statutory and implied warranties, including but not limited to the warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose and non-infringement.“
content.plain_text: Vendors customarily include exclusive warranty and remedy clauses, disclaiming all other express, statutory, and implied warranties (e.g., merchantability, fitness for purpose, non-infringement).
content.expert_insight: This is a standard and critical clause for vendors to limit their liability and define the precise scope of their promises. Zebracorp should expect this.
content.justification: Describes a customary vendor practice and provides an example clause.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should anticipate these clauses and understand their intent to limit supplier liability.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers customarily include these clauses to control their warranty exposure.
content.source_insight: The example clause is a common legal boilerplate for warranty disclaimers.
content.text: It is customary for a vendor to include a provisions stating that the warranties they have provided in the agreement are exclusive i.e. the only and sole warranties given in respect of the sold deliverables. A typical clause would read in e.g. as follows: “The warranties and remedies contained in this [Agreement] are the exclusive warranties and remedies given by the [Seller] and are in lieu of and specifically exclude all other express, statutory and implied warranties, including but not limited to the warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose and non-infringement.“

content.verbatim_text: The reason for the vendor to propose this type of language is the need to exclude the implied warranties that the vendor might otherwise have under the applicable legislation. For instance the United States Uniform Commercial Code provides an implied warranty for merchantability (which means the goods must reasonably conform to an ordinary buyer's expectations) and an implied warranty for fitness for purpose. Many other countries have Commercial Codes that provide comprehensive statutory warranties that will apply unless the parties have agreed otherwise in their respective contract.
content.plain_text: Vendors propose exclusive warranty language to exclude implied warranties (e.g., UCC merchantability, fitness for purpose) that would otherwise apply under legislation in various countries.
content.expert_insight: This explains the legal rationale behind these disclaimers. Understanding the statutory background helps Zebracorp appreciate why vendors push for these clauses.
content.justification: Explains the legal rationale behind exclusive warranty clauses and provides examples of implied warranties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should understand that exclusive clauses aim to override statutory implied warranties.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers use exclusive clauses to override potentially broad statutory implied warranties.
content.source_insight: Highlights the interplay between contract law and statutory law.
content.text: The reason for the vendor to propose this type of language is the need to exclude the implied warranties that the vendor might otherwise have under the applicable legislation. For instance the United States Uniform Commercial Code provides an implied warranty for merchantability (which means the goods must reasonably conform to an ordinary buyer's expectations) and an implied warranty for fitness for purpose. Many other countries have Commercial Codes that provide comprehensive statutory warranties that will apply unless the parties have agreed otherwise in their respective contract.

content.verbatim_text: Excluding these implied and statutory warranties is generally acceptable for Zebracorp. This is because we will be relying exclusively on the warranties that we stipulated in our contract.
content.plain_text: Excluding implied and statutory warranties is generally acceptable for Zebracorp, as it relies exclusively on contractually stipulated warranties.
content.expert_insight: This confirms Zebracorp's strategic preference for clear, express contractual warranties over potentially ambiguous implied ones. It allows for a streamlined contractual relationship.
content.justification: States Zebracorp's general acceptance of disclaiming implied/statutory warranties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can agree to exclude implied/statutory warranties if its own express warranties are robust.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers' requests to exclude implied/statutory warranties are generally acceptable to Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: Reinforces Zebracorp's focus on explicit contractual terms.
content.text: Excluding these implied and statutory warranties is generally acceptable for Zebracorp. This is because we will be relying exclusively on the warranties that we stipulated in our contract.

content.verbatim_text: Also the remedies, that is, the rights of the buyer to in e.g. a refund or a replacement product when a warranty is breached are often exclusively defined in the purchasing contract. In these cases, it is not problematic to accept the above type of language that specifically says that all remedies are exclusively defined in the contract.
content.plain_text: It's not problematic to accept language stating that all remedies (e.g., refund, replacement) for warranty breaches are exclusively defined in the purchasing contract.
content.expert_insight: This extends the principle of exclusivity to remedies. By defining remedies explicitly, Zebracorp gains clarity and avoids relying on potentially uncertain statutory remedies.
content.justification: Extends the acceptance to exclusive remedies, providing clarity for Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can agree that all remedies for warranty breaches are exclusively defined in the contract, provided those remedies are adequate.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can expect Zebracorp to accept language that remedies are exclusively defined in the contract.
content.source_insight: Completes the picture of 'exclusive' clauses, covering both the warranties and the consequences of their breach.
content.text: Also the remedies, that is, the rights of the buyer to in e.g. a refund or a replacement product when a warranty is breached are often exclusively defined in the purchasing contract. In these cases, it is not problematic to accept the above type of language that specifically says that all remedies are exclusively defined in the contract.

content.verbatim_text: Because of the uncertainty surrounding such implied warranties, any prudent supplier/subcontractor would want to limit its liability to the mutually in writing agreed express warranties only, and disclaim all liability for implied warranties.
content.plain_text: Prudent suppliers/subcontractors should limit their liability to only mutually agreed express warranties and disclaim all implied warranties due to their inherent uncertainty.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical risk mitigation strategy for suppliers, emphasizing the need to control warranty exposure by explicitly limiting commitments and disclaiming unwritten obligations.

content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should actively disclaim implied warranties to reduce potential liability and clearly define their obligations.

content.text: Because of the uncertainty surrounding such implied warranties, any prudent supplier/subcontractor would want to limit its liability to the mutually in writing agreed express warranties only, and disclaim all liability for implied warranties.

content.verbatim_text: Whilst ZEBRACORP procurement contract templates do not specifically exclude these type of implied warranties, focusing on express warranties only, and specifically excluding the applicability of implied warranties is generally an acceptable approach.
content.plain_text: While ZEBRACORP's standard templates don't explicitly exclude implied warranties, it is acceptable to focus on express warranties and specifically exclude implied ones.
content.expert_insight: This provides ZEBRACORP with flexibility in its contracting strategy, allowing for the explicit exclusion of implied warranties even if not standard in their templates, aligning with best practices for managing risk.
content.justification: This provides context on ZEBRACORP's existing practices and an acceptable alternative approach.

content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may find Zebracorp receptive to clauses excluding implied warranties.

content.text: Whilst ZEBRACORP procurement contract templates do not specifically exclude these type of implied warranties, focusing on express warranties only, and specifically excluding the applicability of implied warranties is generally an acceptable approach.

content.verbatim_text: It is not unusual to see vendor templates to exclude all warranties from the outset. No warranties, no returns, no come-backs and no responsibility for any defects once the deal is concluded. The purchasing party is expected to live with what it has purchased or without it, as the case may be.
content.plain_text: It is common for vendor contracts to initially exclude all warranties, meaning no returns or responsibility for defects after the sale, leaving the buyer to accept the product as-is.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a common aggressive vendor position, signaling a need for buyers like ZEBRACORP to be vigilant and negotiate appropriate warranty coverage, especially for paid products.
content.justification: This describes a common vendor practice.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be aware of this common vendor stance and be prepared to negotiate for appropriate warranties.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers often attempt to disclaim all warranties, which is a common negotiation tactic.
content.source_insight: The text describes a 'not unusual' vendor practice.
content.text: It is not unusual to see vendor templates to exclude all warranties from the outset. No warranties, no returns, no come-backs and no responsibility for any defects once the deal is concluded. The purchasing party is expected to live with what it has purchased or without it, as the case may be.

content.verbatim_text: These type of all-inclusive warranty disclaimers should be considered for free-of-charge products and services only, and should never be considered when paying market price for a sold product/service.
content.plain_text: All-inclusive warranty disclaimers are only acceptable for free-of-charge products/services and should never be agreed to when paying market price.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial directive for ZEBRACORP, establishing a bright-line rule: a buyer paying market price must secure warranties, otherwise, they bear undue risk. This protects against accepting 'as-is' for paid goods.
content.conditions: Product/service is free-of-charge OR market price is being paid.
content.justification: Accepting such disclaimers for paid products/services exposes the company to unacceptable risk.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must never accept all-inclusive warranty disclaimers for products/services it pays market price for.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to reject all-inclusive warranty disclaimers for paid products/services.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states when these disclaimers 'should' and 'should never' be considered.
content.text: These type of all-inclusive warranty disclaimers should be considered for free-of-charge products and services only, and should never be considered when paying market price for a sold product/service.

content.verbatim_text: Only sample products (prototypes and preproduction units) are generally sold without a warranty, with the understanding that they will not be placed into commercial use and are provided free-of-charge.
content.plain_text: Typically, only free-of-charge sample products (prototypes, preproduction units) are sold without warranties, with the condition that they are not for commercial use.

content.verbatim_text: On top of these warranties, ZEBRACORP generally requires in its procurement contract templates the supplier to warrant that the procured hardware complies with the applicable product specifications and the Zebracorp Quality Requirements, and that the hardware is fit for the purpose for which it was intended.

content.expert_insight: This establishes ZEBRACORP's additional, specific requirements for hardware warranties, going beyond standard defect coverage to ensure functional and quality compliance, which is critical for its operational needs.

content.verbatim_text: However, in most cases, there is really no justification to exclude warranty for non-functionality that is caused by a design defect. ZEBRACORP does not control the design of the product and it would be unreasonable to pass the risk of design defects over to ZEBRACORP. It would be an untenable position if ZEBRACORP would be unable to return products that break down due to defects in the design work.
content.plain_text: There is generally no justification to exclude warranties for non-functionality caused by design defects, as ZEBRACORP does not control product design and should not bear this risk.
content.expert_insight: This provides a strong argument for ZEBRACORP to resist the exclusion of design defect warranties, grounding it in the principle that risk should lie with the party controlling the design.

content.justification: Zebracorp does not control product design, making it unreasonable to bear the risk of design defects. Inability to return products due to design defects is an untenable position.

It would be an untenable position if ZEBRACORP would be unable to return products that break down due to defects in the design work.

The seller could potentially use this qualifier to arbitrarily refuse warranty repairs/replacement requests.

content.justification: Such qualifiers place an undue burden of proof on Zebracorp and allow sellers to arbitrarily refuse warranty claims.

content.verbatim_text: If we nevertheless cannot negotiate away this qualifier, a compromise can be found by saying in e.g. that “the above product warranty does not apply to any such trivial or minor errors that do not affect the functionality or operation of the product”.

content.expert_insight: This offers a pragmatic compromise when facing strong vendor resistance, allowing for some flexibility while still protecting ZEBRACORP from functional defects, distinguishing between cosmetic/minor issues and actual performance failures.
content.conditions: A 'material' qualifier cannot be negotiated away.
content.justification: This provides a compromise that addresses seller concerns while protecting Zebracorp's core interests in product functionality.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can propose this compromise if unable to remove 'material' qualifiers completely.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may find this compromise acceptable if they insist on some form of materiality qualifier.
content.source_insight: The text suggests a 'compromise' if negotiation fails.
content.text: If we nevertheless cannot negotiate away this qualifier, a compromise can be found by saying in e.g. that “the above product warranty does not apply to any such trivial or minor errors that do not affect the functionality or operation of the product”.

content.verbatim_text: In order to align the hardware warranty to the standard warranty offered to Zebracorp customers, we should request at a minimum 24 months warranty.
content.plain_text: To align with Zebracorp's customer offerings, a minimum 24-month hardware warranty should be requested.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a minimum standard for hardware warranty duration, driven by back-to-back warranty alignment with end-customer commitments, crucial for managing downstream liability.
content.conditions: Procuring hardware.
content.justification: To align with Zebracorp's standard warranty offering to its customers.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should aim for at least a 24-month hardware warranty in its procurement contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to request a minimum 24-month hardware warranty.
content.source_insight: The text states 'we should request at a minimum 24 months warranty'.
content.text: In order to align the hardware warranty to the standard warranty offered to Zebracorp customers, we should request at a minimum 24 months warranty.

content.verbatim_text: In direct procurement contracts it is important to extend the warranty period by some months to in e.g. 26-26 months in cases where the warranty kicks in upon delivery to Zebracorp in order to allow sufficient time for the hardware to be installed at the end customer and to be at least provisionally accepted by the end customer.
content.plain_text: For direct procurement where warranty starts upon delivery to Zebracorp, the period should be extended (e.g., to 26-28 months) to allow for end-customer installation and provisional acceptance.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical tactical adjustment for ZEBRACORP to account for the time lag between receiving hardware and its deployment/acceptance by the end customer, ensuring sufficient warranty coverage throughout the supply chain.
content.conditions: Direct procurement contracts where warranty starts upon delivery to Zebracorp.
content.justification: To allow sufficient time for hardware installation and provisional acceptance by the end customer, as end-customer warranties often start from acceptance/delivery to customer sites.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should extend warranty periods in direct procurement to cover end-customer deployment time.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers in direct procurement with Zebracorp may be asked to extend warranty periods beyond standard delivery-based starts.
content.source_insight: The text states 'it is important to extend the warranty period'.
content.text: In direct procurement contracts it is important to extend the warranty period by some months to in e.g. 26-26 months in cases where the warranty kicks in upon delivery to Zebracorp in order to allow sufficient time for the hardware to be installed at the end customer and to be at least provisionally accepted by the end customer.

content.verbatim_text: This is because in most of our end-customer contracts, the warranties start to run from provisional acceptance or date of delivery to customer sites.
content.plain_text: This extension is necessary because most end-customer contracts begin warranties from provisional acceptance or delivery to customer sites.
content.expert_insight: This provides the 'why' behind the previous guideline, emphasizing the need for 'back-to-back' warranty coverage to avoid a gap in protection for ZEBRACORP.
content.justification: This explains the reason for extending warranty periods.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: This is because in most of our end-customer contracts, the warranties start to run from provisional acceptance or date of delivery to customer sites.

content.verbatim_text: Note also that the warranty periods can vary greatly between different type of products.
content.plain_text: Warranty durations can differ significantly across various product types.
content.expert_insight: This serves as a general reminder that warranty periods are not uniform and require product-specific consideration.
content.justification: This provides general information about warranty period variability.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A

content.text: Note also that the warranty periods can vary greatly between different type of products.

content.verbatim_text: When procuring site materials, certain fixed structures such as in e.g. antenna towers and monopoles may require warranties of up to 10-15 years and such extended warranties are generally seen perfectly standard in that industry.
content.plain_text: For site materials like antenna towers, warranties of 10-15 years are common and standard in the industry.
content.expert_insight: This highlights specific industry norms for long-lifecycle assets, informing ZEBRACORP to expect and negotiate for significantly longer warranties in these specialized areas.
content.justification: This provides specific examples of extended warranties in certain industries.
