content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: When procuring site materials, certain fixed structures such as in e.g. antenna towers and monopoles may require warranties of up to 10-15 years and such extended warranties are generally seen perfectly standard in that industry.

content.verbatim_text: Whilst it is in Zebracorp’s interest to be able, not only to have the defective product repaired or replaced, but also to have the right to seek reimbursement for eventual production line stoppage, the time spent tracing defects, testing and similar costs, most vendors will insist that the sole remedy for a breach of a product warranty should be the repair or replacement of the product.
content.plain_text: While Zebracorp wants reimbursement for ancillary costs like production stoppage and defect tracing, most vendors will insist that repair or replacement is the sole remedy for a product warranty breach.
content.expert_insight: This outlines a common conflict in warranty negotiations: the buyer's desire for comprehensive compensation versus the seller's preference for limited, direct remedies. It sets the stage for negotiation tactics.
content.justification: This describes Zebracorp's interests versus common vendor positions regarding warranty remedies.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Whilst it is in Zebracorp’s interest to be able, not only to have the defective product repaired or replaced, but also to have the right to seek reimbursement for eventual production line stoppage, the time spent tracing defects, testing and similar costs, most vendors will insist that the sole remedy for a breach of a product warranty should be the repair or replacement of the product.

content.verbatim_text: Some of Zebracorp procurement contract templates have specific clauses that will give Zebracorp the right to seek compensation for ancillary costs such as those described above.
content.plain_text: Some of Zebracorp's procurement contract templates include clauses allowing Zebracorp to claim compensation for ancillary costs related to warranty breaches.
content.expert_insight: This indicates ZEBRACORP's proactive stance in seeking broader remedies, suggesting these clauses are a key negotiation point to include where possible.
content.justification: This describes a feature of Zebracorp's contract templates.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Some of Zebracorp procurement contract templates have specific clauses that will give Zebracorp the right to seek compensation for ancillary costs such as those described above.

content.verbatim_text: “If [Buyer], due to defective [Products], incurs costs, expenses or damages in connection with production stoppage, line down, de-installation or reinstallation of defective products, or in connection with product defect tracing or product testing and/or such other labour costs, [Supplier] shall reimburse [Buyer] any such costs, expenses and damages.”
content.plain_text: An example clause for ancillary costs states that if the Buyer incurs costs (e.g., production stoppage, de-installation, defect tracing) due to defective products, the Supplier must reimburse these costs.
content.expert_insight: This provides a direct example of a robust clause for ancillary costs, serving as a template or reference for ZEBRACORP's contract drafting and negotiation.
content.justification: This is a direct example provided in the text.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: “If [Buyer], due to defective [Products], incurs costs, expenses or damages in connection with production stoppage, line down, de-installation or reinstallation of defective products, or in connection with product defect tracing or product testing and/or such other labour costs, [Supplier] shall reimburse [Buyer] any such costs, expenses and damages.”

content.verbatim_text: These clauses can be negotiated away under pressure or the list of ancillary costs, for which the seller is liable, can be negotiated and narrowed down.
content.plain_text: Clauses for ancillary costs can be negotiated out or their scope narrowed down under supplier pressure.
content.expert_insight: This acknowledges the reality of negotiation, indicating that these clauses are often contentious and may require concessions, preparing ZEBRACORP for potential pushback.
content.justification: This describes negotiation tactics regarding ancillary cost clauses.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: These clauses can be negotiated away under pressure or the list of ancillary costs, for which the seller is liable, can be negotiated and narrowed down.

content.verbatim_text: Another option would be to retain the clause and, as a compromise, add an obligation on Zebracorp to mitigate any costs, expenses and damages that Zebracorp would seek from the supplier under the clause.
content.plain_text: As a compromise, Zebracorp can retain ancillary cost clauses but add an obligation for Zebracorp to mitigate any such costs and damages sought from the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This offers a balanced compromise, allowing ZEBRACORP to retain the right to claim ancillary costs while addressing supplier concerns about unlimited liability by imposing a mitigation duty on the buyer.
content.conditions: Negotiating ancillary cost clauses with suppliers.
content.justification: This provides a compromise solution that retains the clause while addressing supplier concerns about unlimited liability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should be prepared to accept a mitigation obligation as a compromise for ancillary cost clauses.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may find this compromise acceptable for ancillary cost clauses.
content.source_insight: The text offers 'Another option' for compromise.
content.text: Another option would be to retain the clause and, as a compromise, add an obligation on Zebracorp to mitigate any costs, expenses and damages that Zebracorp would seek from the supplier under the clause.

content.verbatim_text: However, please note that it is still customary to expect that the vendor pays for the logistics and other transportation costs associated with the delivery of the repaired or replaced equipment as part of its standard warranty obligations.
content.plain_text: It is customary for vendors to cover logistics and transportation costs for delivering repaired or replaced equipment as part of their standard warranty obligations.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a clear expectation for vendor responsibility regarding logistics for warranty fulfillment, which ZEBRACORP should uphold as a standard practice.
content.conditions: Equipment is repaired or replaced under warranty.
content.justification: This is a customary expectation as part of standard warranty obligations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should expect vendors to pay for logistics costs for repaired/replaced warranty equipment.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect to cover logistics costs for repaired/replaced equipment under warranty.
content.source_insight: The text states 'it is still customary to expect'.
content.text: However, please note that it is still customary to expect that the vendor pays for the logistics and other transportation costs associated with the delivery of the repaired or replaced equipment as part of its standard warranty obligations.

content.verbatim_text: In certain cases Zebracorp can agree that it will pay for the shipment of the returned product to vendor but it would be highly unusual for Zebracorp as the customer to pay all logistics costs for warranty returns.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may agree to pay for returning a defective product to the vendor in some cases, but paying all logistics costs for warranty returns is highly unusual for a customer.
content.expert_insight: This sets a boundary for ZEBRACORP's willingness to absorb return shipping costs, emphasizing that while partial concession might be possible, full responsibility for warranty return logistics remains with the vendor.
content.conditions: Negotiating logistics costs for warranty returns.
content.justification: Paying all logistics costs for warranty returns is highly unusual for a customer.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should generally avoid paying all logistics costs for warranty returns, though partial payment for shipment to vendor may be considered in specific cases.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should not expect Zebracorp to pay all logistics costs for warranty returns.
content.source_insight: The text describes what Zebracorp 'can agree' versus what would be 'highly unusual'.
content.text: In certain cases Zebracorp can agree that it will pay for the shipment of the returned product to vendor but it would be highly unusual for Zebracorp as the customer to pay all logistics costs for warranty returns.

content.verbatim_text: Sellers will habitually wish to retain the right to choose the appropriate remedy and in most cases it is perfectly acceptable that the seller is provided with the opportunity to honour the warranty by either repairing or replacing the defective product.
content.plain_text: Sellers typically want to choose the warranty remedy (repair or replacement), which is generally acceptable.
content.expert_insight: This indicates a common and acceptable vendor request, allowing them control over the most efficient way to fulfill their warranty obligation.
content.justification: This describes common seller behavior and its general acceptability.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Sellers will habitually wish to retain the right to choose the appropriate remedy and in most cases it is perfectly acceptable that the seller is provided with the opportunity to honour the warranty by either repairing or replacing the defective product.

content.verbatim_text: In case the repair or replace of the product is not feasible, the sellers will generally afford Zebracorp right for a refund i.e. a credit of the purchase price of the product.
content.plain_text: If repair or replacement is not possible, sellers usually offer Zebracorp a refund (credit of the purchase price).
content.expert_insight: This clarifies the typical fallback remedy when primary options (repair/replace) are exhausted, providing an understanding of the expected hierarchy of warranty remedies.
content.justification: This describes a general practice for warranty remedies.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In case the repair or replace of the product is not feasible, the sellers will generally afford Zebracorp right for a refund i.e. a credit of the purchase price of the product.

content.verbatim_text: In case of refund, the seller may wish to limit the refund to a depreciated value of the product in the event the product cannot be repaired or replaced (e.g. if the product has a six year useful life and it fails after two years, the seller may want to limit the refund to 33% of the purchase price instead of 100%). Such depreciation provisions are not unusual. The numbers can always be negotiated.
content.plain_text: Sellers may seek to limit refunds to a depreciated value if repair/replacement is impossible. Such depreciation clauses are common, and the specific terms are negotiable.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a common vendor tactic to reduce financial exposure on refunds, indicating that while depreciation is not unusual, the terms are always subject to negotiation by ZEBRACORP.
content.justification: This describes a common seller desire and negotiation point.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In case of refund, the seller may wish to limit the refund to a depreciated value of the product in the event the product cannot be repaired or replaced (e.g. if the product has a six year useful life and it fails after two years, the seller may want to limit the refund to 33% of the purchase price instead of 100%). Such depreciation provisions are not unusual. The numbers can always be negotiated.

content.verbatim_text: Sophisticated vendors will refuse to give Zebracorp an explicit right to require refund because of revenue recognition concerns.
content.plain_text: Sophisticated vendors often refuse to grant an explicit right to refund due to revenue recognition implications.
content.expert_insight: This explains a key reason for vendor resistance to explicit refund rights, providing ZEBRACORP with insight into supplier motivations during negotiation.
content.justification: This describes a common stance of sophisticated vendors and its reasoning.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Sophisticated vendors will refuse to give Zebracorp an explicit right to require refund because of revenue recognition concerns.

content.verbatim_text: Remaining silent about the refund can often be accepted so long as the agreement contains at a minimum a right for Zebracorp to obtain a repaired or replaced product.
content.plain_text: Silence on refund rights is acceptable if the agreement guarantees Zebracorp the right to a repaired or replaced product.
content.expert_insight: This provides a pragmatic approach for ZEBRACORP, prioritizing the primary remedies (repair/replace) and accepting implicit refund rights as a fallback, especially when explicit rights are difficult to obtain.
content.conditions: Agreement contains a minimum right for Zebracorp to obtain a repaired or replaced product.
content.justification: Prioritizes primary remedies while accepting implicit refund rights.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept contract silence on explicit refund rights if repair/replacement is guaranteed.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may find Zebracorp amenable to omitting explicit refund rights if repair/replacement is guaranteed.
content.source_insight: The text states what 'can often be accepted'.
content.text: Remaining silent about the refund can often be accepted so long as the agreement contains at a minimum a right for Zebracorp to obtain a repaired or replaced product.

content.verbatim_text: Should the supplier be unable to repair/replace the product, we should be able to require refund even in the absence of an explicit contract provision.
content.plain_text: If a supplier cannot repair or replace a product, Zebracorp should be able to demand a refund, even without an explicit contract clause.
content.expert_insight: This asserts an inherent right to a refund when primary remedies fail, reinforcing ZEBRACORP's position even if the contract is silent, relying on general legal principles of contract breach.
content.conditions: Supplier is unable to repair/replace the product.
content.justification: This is a fundamental right when other remedies fail, even if not explicitly stated.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should pursue refunds if repair/replacement fails, regardless of explicit contract language.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be aware that Zebracorp will seek refunds if primary remedies fail, even if not explicitly stated in the contract.
content.source_insight: The text states 'we should be able to require refund'.
content.text: Should the supplier be unable to repair/replace the product, we should be able to require refund even in the absence of an explicit contract provision.

content.verbatim_text: Software warranties can be controversial.
content.plain_text: Software warranties are often a contentious area in contracts.
content.expert_insight: This serves as a general warning that software warranties are a complex and often difficult negotiation point, requiring careful attention.
content.justification: This is a general statement about the nature of software warranties.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Software warranties can be controversial.

content.verbatim_text: Most software vendors, notably those based in North America, have a very conservative and reserved approach on software warranties, and are likely to specifically disclaim any warranties that would imply that software will be bug-free, error-free, or that it will run without interruption.
content.plain_text: North American software vendors typically take a conservative approach, often disclaiming warranties that suggest software will be bug-free, error-free, or uninterrupted.
content.expert_insight: This highlights regional differences and common vendor positions, preparing ZEBRACORP for the typical limitations vendors will seek to impose on software warranties.
content.justification: This describes the common approach of software vendors, especially in North America.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Most software vendors, notably those based in North America, have a very conservative and reserved approach on software warranties, and are likely to specifically disclaim any warranties that would imply that software will be bug-free, error-free, or that it will run without interruption.

content.verbatim_text: Many vendors may also seek to disclaim software warranties altogether and instead say that the software comes on “as is” basis without any warranty of any kind.
content.plain_text: Many vendors attempt to disclaim all software warranties, providing the software 'as is' without any guarantees.
content.expert_insight: This identifies a common, aggressive vendor stance that ZEBRACORP must be prepared to counter, especially for paid software.
content.justification: This describes a common vendor approach to software warranties.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Many vendors may also seek to disclaim software warranties altogether and instead say that the software comes on “as is” basis without any warranty of any kind.

content.verbatim_text: While this may be acceptable for royalty-free software, it is should not be accepted for software that carries a license fee or a price tag.
content.plain_text: Accepting 'as is' software warranties is only suitable for royalty-free software; it must not be accepted for paid software.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical rule for ZEBRACORP, drawing a clear distinction between free and paid software regarding warranty expectations, ensuring that investment in software is protected by appropriate guarantees.
content.conditions: Software carries a license fee or a price tag.
content.justification: Accepting 'as is' for paid software exposes the company to unacceptable risk.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must never accept 'as is' software warranties for paid software.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to reject 'as is' warranties for paid software.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states what 'should not be accepted'.
content.text: While this may be acceptable for royalty-free software, it is should not be accepted for software that carries a license fee or a price tag.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp’s position on software warranty and minimum requirements varies from case to case. Depending on the nature of the software and the business case, it may perfectly sufficient that the software warranty is fairly limited.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's software warranty stance and minimum requirements are flexible, varying based on the software's nature and business case, sometimes allowing for limited warranties.
content.expert_insight: This indicates a pragmatic, risk-based approach to software warranties, allowing ZEBRACORP to tailor its demands based on the specific context and criticality of the software.
content.justification: This describes Zebracorp's flexible approach to software warranties.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Zebracorp’s position on software warranty and minimum requirements varies from case to case. Depending on the nature of the software and the business case, it may perfectly sufficient that the software warranty is fairly limited.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp and our customers often rely on software support – as opposed to software warranty - to deal with the software bugs and day-to-day software error resolution.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp and its customers frequently depend on software support, rather than warranties, for bug fixes and daily error resolution.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the practical reality that ongoing software issues are often handled through support agreements, which influences the perceived importance and scope of the initial software warranty.
content.justification: This describes a common operational reliance on software support.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Zebracorp and our customers often rely on software support – as opposed to software warranty - to deal with the software bugs and day-to-day software error resolution.

content.verbatim_text: In fact in many cases it may be adequate that the licensor warrants that the software is compliant with its specifications, and that the software materially performs all functions described in the product specifications/product documentation.
content.plain_text: In many cases, an adequate software warranty may simply require the licensor to warrant compliance with specifications and material performance of documented functions.
content.expert_insight: This sets a reasonable baseline for software warranties when extensive 'bug-free' guarantees are not feasible or necessary, focusing on core functional compliance.
content.conditions: Specific business case and nature of the software.
content.justification: This is often sufficient given the reliance on software support for ongoing issues.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept a software warranty limited to compliance with specifications and material performance of documented functions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may find Zebracorp agreeable to software warranties limited to compliance with specifications and material performance.
content.source_insight: The text states 'it may be adequate that the licensor warrants'.
content.text: In fact in many cases it may be adequate that the licensor warrants that the software is compliant with its specifications, and that the software materially performs all functions described in the product specifications/product documentation.

content.verbatim_text: In addition to these two warranted items, warranties on software being free from viruses, spyware or other malicious code is often non-contentions and we should seek to include such anti-virus warranty.
content.plain_text: Beyond compliance and material performance, a warranty that software is free from viruses, spyware, or malicious code is often non-contentious and should be sought.
content.expert_insight: This identifies a specific, generally achievable and important warranty for software security, which ZEBRACORP should proactively include.
content.conditions: Procuring software.
content.justification: This is often non-contentious and crucial for security.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should actively seek to include anti-virus/malicious code warranties in software contracts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to request an anti-virus warranty, which is typically non-contentious.
content.source_insight: The text states 'we should seek to include such anti-virus warranty'.
content.text: In addition to these two warranted items, warranties on software being free from viruses, spyware or other malicious code is often non-contentions and we should seek to include such anti-virus warranty.

content.verbatim_text: Note that, unlike with hardware warranties, when it comes to software warranties, it may be perfectly acceptable for the seller to warrant the software only materially meets the specifications. This is because software will inherently have some errors and bugs.
content.plain_text: Unlike hardware, it's often acceptable for software warranties to cover only 'material' compliance with specifications, given software's inherent bugs and errors.
content.expert_insight: This provides a key distinction between hardware and software warranties, justifying the acceptance of 'material' compliance for software due to its inherent complexity and bugginess, which is a pragmatic concession.
content.conditions: Negotiating software warranties.
content.justification: Software inherently contains errors and bugs, making 'material' compliance a more realistic standard.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept 'material' compliance for software warranties, unlike for hardware.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may successfully negotiate for 'material' compliance in software warranties with Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly notes this difference and states it 'may be perfectly acceptable'.
content.text: Note that, unlike with hardware warranties, when it comes to software warranties, it may be perfectly acceptable for the seller to warrant the software only materially meets the specifications. This is because software will inherently have some errors and bugs.

content.verbatim_text: However, it is also possible that we are relying on the software warranty instead of software support, and elect not to purchase software support for the duration of the warranty. It is also possible that the our end customer requires a warranty on software being error-free, in which case we are, for obvious reasons, inclined to look for similar warranty on our software vendor. In these cases, it is important to have a warranty for software being free from errors and to have the licensor commit to resolve any errors within the resolution times that are specified in the support agreement.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp relies solely on software warranty (no support) or if end customers require error-free software, it's crucial to secure an error-free warranty and a commitment from the licensor to resolve errors within support agreement times.
content.expert_insight: This outlines specific scenarios where a more stringent 'error-free' software warranty is essential, driven by either internal strategy (no support purchase) or external customer demands, requiring the licensor to commit to timely resolution.
content.conditions: Zebracorp relies on software warranty instead of support OR end customer requires error-free software.
content.justification: To meet internal reliance on warranty or back-to-back end-customer commitments.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must prioritize error-free software warranties and resolution commitments in specific high-reliance or end-customer-driven scenarios.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to demand error-free software warranties with resolution commitments under specific circumstances.
content.source_insight: The text states 'it is important to have a warranty for software being free from errors'.
content.text: However, it is also possible that we are relying on the software warranty instead of software support, and elect not to purchase software support for the duration of the warranty. It is also possible that the our end customer requires a warranty on software being error-free, in which case we are, for obvious reasons, inclined to look for similar warranty on our software vendor. In these cases, it is important to have a warranty for software being free from errors and to have the licensor commit to resolve any errors within the resolution times that are specified in the support agreement.

content.verbatim_text: In order to make the warranty on error-free more palatable for the licensor, it may be worthwhile specifying that the software error correction measures are our sole remedy and the licensor’s sole liability for failure to meet this type of a warranty. This is because the software vendor will wish to have clear visibility as the eventual consequences of warranting that the software is error-free while knowing full well that the software will have bugs and errors.
content.plain_text: To make an error-free software warranty more acceptable to the licensor, specify that error correction measures are Zebracorp's sole remedy and the licensor's sole liability for breach.
content.expert_insight: This offers a strategic concession to secure an 'error-free' warranty, limiting the licensor's financial exposure to remediation efforts rather than broader damages, balancing robust warranty coverage with vendor commercial realities.
content.conditions: Seeking an 'error-free' software warranty from a reluctant licensor.
content.justification: To make the 'error-free' warranty more palatable to the licensor by limiting their liability to error correction, addressing their concerns about inherent software bugs.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp may need to limit remedies to error correction for error-free software warranties.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may accept an 'error-free' software warranty if their liability is limited to error correction measures.
content.source_insight: The text states 'it may be worthwhile specifying' this compromise.
content.text: In order to make the warranty on error-free more palatable for the licensor, it may be worthwhile specifying that the software error correction measures are our sole remedy and the licensor’s sole liability for failure to meet this type of a warranty. This is because the software vendor will wish to have clear visibility as the eventual consequences of warranting that the software is error-free while knowing full well that the software will have bugs and errors.

content.verbatim_text: Many vendors are keen to propose a warranty that essentially says that the media on which the software is delivered is errorfree.
content.plain_text: Many vendors propose warranties that only cover the delivery media (e.g., DVD) for software, ensuring it is error-free.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a common vendor tactic to offer a minimal warranty, which ZEBRACORP needs to recognize as insufficient for actual software quality.
content.justification: This describes a common vendor proposal.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Many vendors are keen to propose a warranty that essentially says that the media on which the software is delivered is errorfree.

content.verbatim_text: Note that this is not the same as warranting that the software itself is free from errors. This type of warranty only provides that the actual media on which the software is delivered i.e. that the DVD that contained the software is not defective. This type of a warranty on the delivery medium does not provide much added-value to Zebracorp, and it is not a substitute for a proper software warranty, and should not be mistaken for an actual software warranty.
content.plain_text: A warranty on software delivery media is not a substitute for a proper software warranty, as it only covers the physical medium, not the software's functionality, and offers little value to Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical warning for ZEBRACORP to distinguish between a trivial media warranty and a substantive software warranty, preventing acceptance of inadequate coverage.
content.conditions: Vendors propose a warranty on the software delivery media.
content.justification: A media warranty provides minimal value and is not a substitute for an actual software warranty, potentially misleading the buyer.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must not accept a software delivery media warranty as a substitute for a proper software warranty.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers offering only media warranties for software should expect Zebracorp to reject them as insufficient.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly warns that this type of warranty 'should not be mistaken for an actual software warranty'.
content.text: Note that this is not the same as warranting that the software itself is free from errors. This type of warranty only provides that the actual media on which the software is delivered i.e. that the DVD that contained the software is not defective. This type of a warranty on the delivery medium does not provide much added-value to Zebracorp, and it is not a substitute for a proper software warranty, and should not be mistaken for an actual software warranty.

content.verbatim_text: It is not mandatory to have the supplier warrant that the software complies with the Zebracorp Quality Requirements Appendix so long as the supplier has elsewhere in the contract agreed to comply with such requirements.
content.plain_text: It's not mandatory for suppliers to specifically warrant software compliance with the Zebracorp Quality Requirements Appendix if compliance is already agreed upon elsewhere in the contract.
content.expert_insight: This provides flexibility, avoiding redundant clauses if compliance is already established, streamlining contract language without sacrificing protection.
content.conditions: Supplier has elsewhere in the contract agreed to comply with Zebracorp Quality Requirements.
content.justification: Avoids redundancy if compliance is already covered.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp does not need a separate warranty clause for Quality Requirements if compliance is ensured elsewhere.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may not need to include a specific warranty for Zebracorp Quality Requirements if already committed elsewhere.
content.source_insight: The text states 'It is not mandatory to have the supplier warrant'.
content.text: It is not mandatory to have the supplier warrant that the software complies with the Zebracorp Quality Requirements Appendix so long as the supplier has elsewhere in the contract agreed to comply with such requirements.

content.verbatim_text: Also when our contract templates has a qualifier saying in e.g. that the software must be ‘strictly’ compliant with the specifications or other agreed requirements, then agreeing to remove such qualifier should not be problematic.
content.plain_text: Removing qualifiers like 'strictly' compliant from software warranty clauses in contract templates should not be problematic.
content.expert_insight: This allows for a more reasonable standard of compliance for software, acknowledging its inherent complexities without undermining essential quality expectations.
content.conditions: Contract templates include 'strictly' compliant qualifiers for software.
content.justification: Removes an overly stringent requirement for software, which inherently has some errors, without significant negative impact.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can agree to remove 'strictly' compliant qualifiers for software.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may find Zebracorp agreeable to removing 'strictly' compliant qualifiers for software.
content.source_insight: The text states 'agreeing to remove such qualifier should not be problematic'.
content.text: Also when our contract templates has a qualifier saying in e.g. that the software must be ‘strictly’ compliant with the specifications or other agreed requirements, then agreeing to remove such qualifier should not be problematic.

content.verbatim_text: Depending on the circumstances, it is generally recommended to require a warranty on backward compatibility at least as regards to certain software applications.
content.plain_text: Depending on the situation, a backward compatibility warranty is generally recommended for certain software applications.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the importance of backward compatibility for maintaining system integrity, especially for critical software, and suggests including this warranty where relevant.
content.conditions: Relevant software applications and circumstances.
content.justification: Ensures system integrity and functionality with older versions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should consider requiring backward compatibility warranties for specific software applications.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may be asked by Zebracorp to provide backward compatibility warranties for certain software.
content.source_insight: The text states 'it is generally recommended to require a warranty on backward compatibility'.
content.text: Depending on the circumstances, it is generally recommended to require a warranty on backward compatibility at least as regards to certain software applications.

content.verbatim_text: This can be achieved by inserting in e.g. the following provision: “The [Licensor] warrants that with respect to any [Upgrade], that each subsequent [Upgrade] will contain the same functionality of the previous [Upgrade] and that such [Upgrade] (N) will be compatible with [two] previous [Upgrades] (N-2) and all [Updates] associated with such [Upgrade].“
content.plain_text: A backward compatibility warranty can be achieved with a provision like: 'The [Licensor] warrants that each subsequent [Upgrade] will retain previous functionality and be compatible with [two] previous [Upgrades] (N-2) and all associated [Updates].'
content.expert_insight: This provides a specific contractual clause for backward compatibility, offering a concrete tool for ZEBRACORP to implement this warranty.
content.justification: This is a direct example provided in the text.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: This can be achieved by inserting in e.g. the following provision: “The [Licensor] warrants that with respect to any [Upgrade], that each subsequent [Upgrade] will contain the same functionality of the previous [Upgrade] and that such [Upgrade] (N) will be compatible with [two] previous [Upgrades] (N-2) and all [Updates] associated with such [Upgrade].“

content.verbatim_text: These compatibility warranties are often limited to the current release and the two most previous releases. This is often referred to as N-2 where “N” is the current release. The compatibility warranty is however often limited to the current release and the immediately preceding major release only i.e. N-1.
content.plain_text: Compatibility warranties are often limited to the current release and the two previous releases (N-2), or more commonly, to the current and immediately preceding major release (N-1).
content.expert_insight: This clarifies the common scope and terminology (N-1, N-2) for compatibility warranties, informing ZEBRACORP about typical industry limitations.
content.justification: This describes common limitations and terminology for compatibility warranties.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: These compatibility warranties are often limited to the current release and the two most previous releases. This is often referred to as N-2 where “N” is the current release. The compatibility warranty is however often limited to the current release and the immediately preceding major release only i.e. N-1.

content.verbatim_text: This is generally acceptable whenever Zebracorp has adequate visibility to the software release cycle through roadmaps or otherwise, and/or where Zebracorp can somehow control such release cycle.
content.plain_text: An N-1 compatibility warranty is generally acceptable if Zebracorp has sufficient visibility into or control over the software release cycle.
content.expert_insight: This provides a condition for accepting a more limited compatibility warranty (N-1), linking acceptability to ZEBRACORP's ability to manage its own software environment effectively.
content.conditions: Zebracorp has adequate visibility to or control over the software release cycle.
content.justification: Visibility/control over the release cycle allows Zebracorp to manage potential compatibility issues.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept N-1 compatibility warranties if it has sufficient control/visibility over the software release cycle.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may successfully negotiate N-1 compatibility warranties if Zebracorp has release cycle visibility/control.
content.source_insight: The text states this is 'generally acceptable whenever' certain conditions are met.
content.text: This is generally acceptable whenever Zebracorp has adequate visibility to the software release cycle through roadmaps or otherwise, and/or where Zebracorp can somehow control such release cycle.

content.verbatim_text: The software warranty may start to run from date of activation, customer acceptance or date of delivery to Zebracorp, or such other mutually agreed point in time.
content.plain_text: Software warranties can commence from various points, such as activation, customer acceptance, delivery to Zebracorp, or another mutually agreed date.
content.expert_insight: This outlines the flexibility in defining the start date of software warranties, indicating a point of negotiation to align with operational realities.
content.justification: This describes various possible start dates for software warranties.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The software warranty may start to run from date of activation, customer acceptance or date of delivery to Zebracorp, or such other mutually agreed point in time.

content.verbatim_text: As with hardware warranty, it is important to make sure that the duration of the warranty is back-to-back with our end customer commitments whenever we agree that warranty starts already when the software is delivered to ZEBRACORP.
content.plain_text: Similar to hardware, if a software warranty starts upon delivery to ZEBRACORP, its duration must align back-to-back with end-customer commitments.
content.expert_insight: This reiterates the critical 'back-to-back' principle for software warranties, ensuring ZEBRACORP is not exposed to a warranty gap between its supplier and its end customers.
content.conditions: Software warranty starts upon delivery to ZEBRACORP.
content.justification: To ensure continuous warranty coverage and avoid gaps between supplier and end-customer commitments.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure software warranty durations align with end-customer commitments, especially if the warranty starts early.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to align software warranty durations with its end-customer commitments.
content.source_insight: The text states 'it is important to make sure'.
content.text: As with hardware warranty, it is important to make sure that the duration of the warranty is back-to-back with our end customer commitments whenever we agree that warranty starts already when the software is delivered to ZEBRACORP.

content.verbatim_text: In the event the licensor is reluctant to agree to tie the start of the warranty to our end customer acceptance or date of activation, we may need to adjust the duration of warranty period where necessary so that end customer can avail itself to certain minimum warranty term.
content.plain_text: If a licensor won't tie the warranty start to end-customer acceptance or activation, Zebracorp may need to adjust the warranty duration to ensure the end customer receives a minimum term.
content.expert_insight: This provides a practical solution for maintaining end-customer warranty coverage when a supplier is inflexible on the start date, allowing ZEBRACORP to adjust the overall duration.
content.conditions: Licensor is reluctant to tie warranty start to end-customer acceptance or activation.
content.justification: To ensure the end customer receives a certain minimum warranty term, even if the start date cannot be aligned.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp may need to negotiate longer warranty periods if the start date cannot be aligned with end-customer acceptance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may be asked to extend warranty durations if they refuse to align the start date with end-customer acceptance.
content.source_insight: The text states 'we may need to adjust the duration'.
content.text: In the event the licensor is reluctant to agree to tie the start of the warranty to our end customer acceptance or date of activation, we may need to adjust the duration of warranty period where necessary so that end customer can avail itself to certain minimum warranty term.

content.verbatim_text: Note that we should be careful to accept any verbiage, which says that the warranty starts from the first date of delivery/installation since this addition may imply that the software warranty only applies to the initial first delivery of the software and not to any subsequent deliveries.
content.plain_text: Be cautious of contract language stating the warranty starts from the 'first date of delivery/installation,' as it might limit coverage to only the initial software delivery, excluding subsequent ones.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical warning about ambiguous wording that could severely limit warranty coverage, emphasizing the need for precise language to ensure all software deliveries are covered.
content.conditions: Contract language states warranty starts from 'first date of delivery/installation'.
content.justification: This phrasing can limit warranty applicability only to the initial delivery, excluding subsequent ones.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must carefully review and reject/clarify any 'first date of delivery/installation' language to ensure comprehensive warranty coverage.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers using 'first date of delivery/installation' language should expect scrutiny from Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text states 'we should be careful to accept any verbiage'.
content.text: Note that we should be careful to accept any verbiage, which says that the warranty starts from the first date of delivery/installation since this addition may imply that the software warranty only applies to the initial first delivery of the software and not to any subsequent deliveries.

content.verbatim_text: The typical duration for a software warranty ranges from ninety days to twelve months.

content.justification: This describes the typical range for software warranty durations.

content.implication_supplier: N/A

content.text: The typical duration for a software warranty ranges from ninety days to twelve months.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp standard warranty offering to its end customers typically extends to ninety days.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's standard software warranty for end customers is usually ninety days.
content.expert_insight: This provides internal context for ZEBRACORP's own customer commitments, which can influence its negotiation strategy with suppliers.
content.justification: This describes Zebracorp's internal standard.

content.implication_supplier: N/A

content.text: Zebracorp standard warranty offering to its end customers typically extends to ninety days.

content.verbatim_text: In many countries where we operate it may not be uncommon to see software warranties of up to twelve months, or even longer. Such warranties are fairly prevalent in particular in the European countries as opposed to the US market where the software warranties are as a rule limited to ninety days or six months.
content.plain_text: Software warranties can extend to twelve months or more in many countries, especially in Europe, contrasting with the typical 90-day or six-month limits in the US market.
content.expert_insight: This highlights geographical variations in software warranty norms, crucial for ZEBRACORP to consider when contracting in different regions.
content.justification: This describes regional differences in software warranty durations.

Such warranties are fairly prevalent in particular in the European countries as opposed to the US market where the software warranties are as a rule limited to ninety days or six months.

content.verbatim_text: Note however at the antivirus warranty does not necessarily need to apply over an extended period of time but it may be sufficient that the warranty applies only on the software at the time of delivery.
content.plain_text: An antivirus warranty for software may only need to apply at the time of delivery, rather than over an extended period.
content.expert_insight: This provides flexibility for antivirus warranties, recognizing that ongoing protection is often handled by separate security solutions or updates, thus reducing the need for an extended warranty period for this specific aspect.
content.conditions: Negotiating antivirus warranty for software.
content.justification: Ongoing antivirus protection is often handled by separate mechanisms, making an extended warranty for this specific aspect less critical.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept antivirus warranties that apply only at the time of software delivery.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may successfully limit antivirus warranties to the time of delivery.
content.source_insight: The text states 'it may be sufficient that the warranty applies only on the software at the time of delivery'.
content.text: Note however at the antivirus warranty does not necessarily need to apply over an extended period of time but it may be sufficient that the warranty applies only on the software at the time of delivery.

content.verbatim_text: Sophisticated vendors may seek to exclude their liability for warranty failures in certain circumstances, where the failure is caused by acts or omissions of Zebracorp or the end user of the product, or for damage that occurs outside what would be the ordinary or expected use for the product.
content.plain_text: Sophisticated vendors may try to exclude warranty liability for failures caused by Zebracorp's or the end user's actions/omissions, or damage from non-ordinary use.
content.expert_insight: This describes common vendor strategies for limiting their warranty exposure, which ZEBRACORP needs to anticipate and carefully evaluate.
content.justification: This describes common vendor attempts to limit warranty liability.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Sophisticated vendors may seek to exclude their liability for warranty failures in certain circumstances, where the failure is caused by acts or omissions of Zebracorp or the end user of the product, or for damage that occurs outside what would be the ordinary or expected use for the product.

content.verbatim_text: The supplier may as an example request the following exclusions: Misuse, abuse or improper use; Operation beyond specifications or external factors such as temperature, humidity, corrosive elements; Use in combination with products not supplier by the vendor; Improper installation; Lack of proper maintenance; and - Repair by other than the vendor.
content.plain_text: Examples of warranty exclusions suppliers may request include: misuse, abuse, improper use; operation beyond specifications or external factors; use with non-vendor products; improper installation; lack of proper maintenance; and repair by unauthorized parties.
content.expert_insight: This provides a comprehensive list of common warranty exclusions, serving as a checklist for ZEBRACORP to review and negotiate against.
content.justification: This is a direct list of examples provided in the text.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The supplier may as an example request the following exclusions: Misuse, abuse or improper use; Operation beyond specifications or external factors such as temperature, humidity, corrosive elements; Use in combination with products not supplier by the vendor; Improper installation; Lack of proper maintenance; and - Repair by other than the vendor.

content.verbatim_text: Some exclusions can be so broad that almost anything will negate the warranty, and care should be taken when agreeing to these.
content.plain_text: Some warranty exclusions are overly broad and can negate the warranty for almost any reason, requiring extreme caution when agreeing to them.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical warning about the danger of broad exclusions, emphasizing the need for meticulous review to prevent the warranty from becoming effectively meaningless.
content.conditions: Reviewing proposed warranty exclusions.
content.justification: Overly broad exclusions can effectively negate the entire warranty.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must exercise extreme caution and scrutinize all proposed warranty exclusions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to carefully review and challenge broad warranty exclusions.
content.source_insight: The text states 'care should be taken when agreeing to these'.
content.text: Some exclusions can be so broad that almost anything will negate the warranty, and care should be taken when agreeing to these.

content.verbatim_text: Each exclusion should be capable of being objectively measured, and we should not accept any of the above exclusions without careful consideration on a case-by-case basis.
content.plain_text: Every warranty exclusion must be objectively measurable, and none should be accepted without careful, case-by-case consideration.
content.expert_insight: This sets a high bar for accepting exclusions, demanding clarity and measurability to prevent subjective interpretation that could favor the supplier.
content.conditions: Reviewing proposed warranty exclusions.
content.justification: Ensures clarity, prevents arbitrary application, and protects Zebracorp from subjective interpretations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure all warranty exclusions are objectively measurable and are reviewed individually.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should be prepared to justify the objective measurability of their proposed warranty exclusions.
content.source_insight: The text states 'we should not accept any of the above exclusions without careful consideration'.
content.text: Each exclusion should be capable of being objectively measured, and we should not accept any of the above exclusions without careful consideration on a case-by-case basis.

content.verbatim_text: Also failure of the product to meet the warranty has to be solely due to such excluded event or circumstance.
content.plain_text: For a warranty exclusion to apply, the product's failure must be solely attributable to the excluded event or circumstance.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial causation requirement, preventing suppliers from using minor excluded factors to deny warranty claims when the primary cause is a product defect.
content.conditions: Applying a warranty exclusion.
content.justification: Prevents suppliers from using minor excluded factors to deny warranty claims when the primary cause is a product defect.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure that warranty exclusions are only applied if the excluded event is the sole cause of failure.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must demonstrate that the excluded event was the sole cause of failure for an exclusion to apply.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states this requirement.
content.text: Also failure of the product to meet the warranty has to be solely due to such excluded event or circumstance.

content.verbatim_text: The exclusion of misuse or abuse is generally acceptable.
content.plain_text: Exclusions for misuse or abuse are generally acceptable.
content.expert_insight: This indicates a standard and reasonable exclusion that ZEBRACORP can typically agree to, as it aligns with the buyer's responsibility for proper product handling.
content.conditions: Considering warranty exclusions.
content.justification: It is reasonable to exclude warranty coverage for misuse or abuse by the user.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can generally accept exclusions for misuse or abuse.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can expect Zebracorp to generally accept exclusions for misuse or abuse.
content.source_insight: The text states this is 'generally acceptable'.
content.text: The exclusion of misuse or abuse is generally acceptable.

content.verbatim_text: However the term improper use can subjective and we should be careful to accept that exclusion. As long as the product is used in accordance and in compIiance with the specifications, the use should not be improper. Instead of excluding ‘improper use’ we should exclude use outside the product specifications.
content.plain_text: The term 'improper use' is subjective and should be carefully considered; instead, exclude 'use outside the product specifications' to ensure objectivity.
content.expert_insight: This provides a critical refinement for ZEBRACORP, replacing a subjective term ('improper use') with an objective, measurable standard ('use outside product specifications') to prevent arbitrary denial of warranty claims.
content.conditions: Suppliers propose 'improper use' exclusion.
content.justification: 'Improper use' is subjective and can be arbitrarily applied; 'use outside product specifications' is objective and measurable.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should negotiate to replace 'improper use' exclusions with 'use outside product specifications'.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to challenge 'improper use' exclusions and propose 'use outside product specifications' instead.
content.source_insight: The text states 'we should be careful to accept' and 'Instead of excluding… we should exclude'.
content.text: However the term improper use can subjective and we should be careful to accept that exclusion. As long as the product is used in accordance and in compIiance with the specifications, the use should not be improper. Instead of excluding ‘improper use’ we should exclude use outside the product specifications.

content.verbatim_text: The same applies to requests to exclude failures caused by operation of the products beyond their capabilities. The operating parameters should be spelled out in the product specification, and should we, or our end customer, fail to observe those, then and only then it is reasonable that the supplier of the product is excused from its warranty obligations.
content.plain_text: Exclusions for operation beyond product capabilities are reasonable only if operating parameters are clearly defined in specifications and Zebracorp/end customers fail to observe them.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces the need for clear, documented specifications as the basis for any exclusions related to product operation, ensuring that the supplier's liability is tied to agreed-upon performance boundaries.
content.conditions: Suppliers request to exclude failures caused by operation beyond product capabilities.
content.justification: Supplier's excuse from warranty obligations is reasonable only if operating parameters are clearly defined and the buyer fails to observe them.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure operating parameters are clearly specified and only accept such exclusions if non-observance occurs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must ensure operating parameters are clearly documented to justify such exclusions.
content.source_insight: The text states 'then and only then it is reasonable that the supplier... is excused'.
content.text: The same applies to requests to exclude failures caused by operation of the products beyond their capabilities. The operating parameters should be spelled out in the product specification, and should we, or our end customer, fail to observe those, then and only then it is reasonable that the supplier of the product is excused from its warranty obligations.

content.verbatim_text: Excluding supplier’s warranty to use of product in combination with other products is not acceptable as such. We do use our suppliers’ products in conjunction with our own or third party products and equipment. If we were to agree to this exclusion, we should specify that the combination itself must cause the failure in the product, and the combination must not have been known to the supplier or recommended or otherwise permitted by the supplier.
content.plain_text: Excluding warranties for product use in combination with other products is unacceptable. If agreed, it must be specified that the combination solely caused the failure and was unknown/unpermitted by the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical stance for ZEBRACORP, as integration with other products is common. It protects against blanket exclusions by requiring strict causation and supplier awareness/approval for such an exclusion to apply.
content.conditions: Suppliers propose excluding warranty for use in combination with other products.
content.justification: Zebracorp routinely uses supplier products with other equipment. Such an exclusion would be too broad without strict conditions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should strongly reject blanket exclusions for combined product use and impose strict conditions if such an exclusion is negotiated.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers proposing this exclusion should expect strong resistance and demands for strict conditions from Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text states 'is not acceptable as such' and 'we should specify'.
content.text: Excluding supplier’s warranty to use of product in combination with other products is not acceptable as such. We do use our suppliers’ products in conjunction with our own or third party products and equipment. If we were to agree to this exclusion, we should specify that the combination itself must cause the failure in the product, and the combination must not have been known to the supplier or recommended or otherwise permitted by the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: The lack of proper maintenance can also be difficult to measure objectively. When agreeing to such exclusion we should verify how proper maintenance is specified in the product specification and product documentation, and whether such maintenance recommendations are reasonable taken into account the nature and planned use of the products/equipment.
content.plain_text: Due to objectivity concerns, when agreeing to a 'lack of proper maintenance' exclusion, Zebracorp must verify maintenance specifications in documentation and assess their reasonableness for the product's nature and intended use.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the need for objective criteria for 'proper maintenance,' ensuring that any exclusion is based on clear, reasonable, and documented requirements, preventing arbitrary warranty denials.
content.conditions: Suppliers propose 'lack of proper maintenance' exclusion.
content.justification: Ensures objectivity and reasonableness of maintenance requirements to prevent arbitrary warranty denials.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must scrutinize maintenance specifications and their reasonableness before accepting 'lack of proper maintenance' exclusions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must provide clear, reasonable, and documented maintenance specifications to justify 'lack of proper maintenance' exclusions.
content.source_insight: The text states 'we should verify' when agreeing to this exclusion.
content.text: The lack of proper maintenance can also be difficult to measure objectively. When agreeing to such exclusion we should verify how proper maintenance is specified in the product specification and product documentation, and whether such maintenance recommendations are reasonable taken into account the nature and planned use of the products/equipment.

content.verbatim_text: Improper installation can be usually accepted as a warranty exclusion provided that the installation is done performed by the supplier or any third party authorized by it.
content.plain_text: Improper installation can be an acceptable warranty exclusion if the installation was performed by the supplier or an authorized third party.
content.expert_insight: This provides a condition under which 'improper installation' is a reasonable exclusion, placing the responsibility on the party performing the installation, especially when it's not the end-user.
content.conditions: Installation is performed by the supplier or a third party authorized by it.
content.justification: The responsibility for proper installation lies with the party performing it.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept improper installation as an exclusion if the supplier or its authorized party performed the installation.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can propose improper installation as an exclusion if they or their authorized parties performed the installation.
content.source_insight: The text states 'can be usually accepted as a warranty exclusion provided that'.
content.text: Improper installation can be usually accepted as a warranty exclusion provided that the installation is done performed by the supplier or any third party authorized by it.

content.verbatim_text: In each of the above cases, we should specify that the misuse, unauthorized combination etc. was the actual cause of the product failing to meet the warranty.
content.plain_text: For every exclusion, it must be specified that the excluded event (e.g., misuse, unauthorized combination) was the actual cause of the product's warranty failure.
content.expert_insight: This is a fundamental principle of causation for all exclusions, ensuring that the supplier cannot deny a warranty claim unless the excluded event directly and actually caused the failure, preventing opportunistic denials.
content.conditions: Agreeing to any warranty exclusion.
content.justification: Ensures that the excluded event is the direct and actual cause of the failure, preventing arbitrary warranty denials.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure that all warranty exclusions explicitly link the excluded event as the actual cause of failure.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be able to prove actual causation by an excluded event for a warranty exclusion to apply.
content.source_insight: The text states 'we should specify that the misuse, unauthorized combination etc. was the actual cause'.
content.text: In each of the above cases, we should specify that the misuse, unauthorized combination etc. was the actual cause of the product failing to meet the warranty.

content.verbatim_text: Repair by others should not automatically void a warranty. Zebracorp or our customers may routinely use third party repair shops or elect to do self-maintenance.
content.plain_text: Warranty should not be automatically voided by repairs performed by third parties, as Zebracorp and its customers may use external repair shops or perform self-maintenance.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical protection for ZEBRACORP, recognizing its operational flexibility and preventing suppliers from voiding warranties simply because a non-authorized party performed repairs, especially if those repairs were not the cause of the defect.
content.conditions: Suppliers propose 'repair by others' as a warranty exclusion.
content.justification: Zebracorp and its customers routinely use third-party repair or self-maintenance, and such repairs should not automatically void a warranty unless they directly cause the defect.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should resist 'repair by others' automatically voiding a warranty.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should not expect 'repair by others' to automatically void a warranty when contracting with Zebracorp.
content.source_insight: The text states 'should not automatically void a warranty'.
content.text: Repair by others should not automatically void a warranty. Zebracorp or our customers may routinely use third party repair shops or elect to do self-maintenance.

content.verbatim_text: In addition, some vendors seek to exclude warranty in case Zebracorp’s tests have failed to detect a defect. This type of exclusion should be generally rejected. Zebracorp does not test the product against any and all requirement specification requirements and even if we did, not all the faults appear in the testing but only after a while in use. The very idea with warranty is to provide the purchasing party with the right to return products that experience defects after their installation and initial testing.
content.plain_text: Excluding warranty because Zebracorp's tests failed to detect a defect should be rejected. Zebracorp's testing is not exhaustive, and defects can emerge post-initial testing; warranty covers defects appearing after installation and initial use.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical rejection of an unfair exclusion, asserting the fundamental purpose of a warranty: to cover defects that manifest during actual use, beyond initial testing. It protects ZEBRACORP from bearing the burden of latent defects.
content.conditions: Vendors seek to exclude warranty if Zebracorp's tests failed to detect a defect.
content.justification: Zebracorp's testing is not exhaustive, and defects can appear later; the purpose of a warranty is to cover defects discovered after installation and initial testing.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must generally reject warranty exclusions based on its own testing's failure to detect defects.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to reject warranty exclusions based on Zebracorp's testing failures.
content.source_insight: The text states 'This type of exclusion should be generally rejected' and provides strong justification.
content.text: In addition, some vendors seek to exclude warranty in case Zebracorp’s tests have failed to detect a defect. This type of exclusion should be generally rejected. Zebracorp does not test the product against any and all requirement specification requirements and even if we did, not all the faults appear in the testing but only after a while in use. The very idea with warranty is to provide the purchasing party with the right to return products that experience defects after their installation and initial testing.

content.verbatim_text: Services warranties i.e. warranties in relation to the performance of service have often more limited practical relevance as compared to product warranties. This is predominantly due to the fact that most services are in any event subject to acceptance, while ongoing services such as in e.g. maintenance and support are subject to service level agreements and KPIs.
content.plain_text: Service warranties often have less practical relevance than product warranties because services are typically subject to acceptance, and ongoing services are governed by SLAs and KPIs.
content.expert_insight: This explains why service warranties are less emphasized, directing attention to acceptance criteria and SLAs as the primary mechanisms for ensuring service quality, which is important for ZEBRACORP's contract management strategy.
content.justification: This explains the reasons for the limited practical relevance of service warranties.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Services warranties i.e. warranties in relation to the performance of service have often more limited practical relevance as compared to product warranties. This is predominantly due to the fact that most services are in any event subject to acceptance, while ongoing services such as in e.g. maintenance and support are subject to service level agreements and KPIs.

content.verbatim_text: The service warranty that provides that the services are rendered in professional and skilful manner is a minimum requirement and should be non-contentious.
content.plain_text: A service warranty guaranteeing professional and skillful service delivery is a minimum, non-contentious requirement.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a baseline, universally acceptable standard for service warranties, ensuring a fundamental level of quality in service provision.
content.conditions: Procuring services.
content.justification: This is a fundamental and non-contentious expectation for service quality.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should always include a warranty for professional and skillful service delivery.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to require a warranty for professional and skillful service delivery.
content.source_insight: The text states this is a 'minimum requirement and should be non-contentious'.
content.text: The service warranty that provides that the services are rendered in professional and skilful manner is a minimum requirement and should be non-contentious.

content.verbatim_text: In contrast to a product warranty, it is not uncommon to have a service warranty with no defined warranty period. Whenever a specific warranty period is defined, the warranty should start to run from the date of acceptance. The duration of the warranty period should be sufficient to enable us to verify the results of the service and to have any deficiencies rectified.
content.plain_text: Unlike product warranties, service warranties may lack a defined period. If a period is specified, it should start from acceptance and be long enough for Zebracorp to verify results and rectify deficiencies.
content.expert_insight: This provides guidance on structuring service warranty periods, emphasizing the importance of alignment with the service acceptance process and sufficient time for validation.
content.conditions: Defining a service warranty period.
content.justification: Ensures sufficient time for Zebracorp to verify service results and address deficiencies.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure any defined service warranty period starts from acceptance and is adequate for verification.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to seek service warranty periods starting from acceptance and allowing for verification.
content.source_insight: The text provides instructions on how service warranty periods 'should' be defined.
content.text: In contrast to a product warranty, it is not uncommon to have a service warranty with no defined warranty period. Whenever a specific warranty period is defined, the warranty should start to run from the date of acceptance. The duration of the warranty period should be sufficient to enable us to verify the results of the service and to have any deficiencies rectified.

content.verbatim_text: The time frames used in our contract templates are examples only and should be modified on case-by-case basis.
content.plain_text: The time frames in Zebracorp's contract templates are examples and should be adjusted case-by-case.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes flexibility, reinforcing the need for tailored contract terms rather than rigid adherence to templates.
content.justification: This provides instruction on the use of contract templates.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The time frames used in our contract templates are examples only and should be modified on case-by-case basis.

content.verbatim_text: The remedy for failure to meet a service warranty is typically the re-performance of the respective service. Most Zebracorp procurement contract templates do not specify such remedies, but having these remedies specified is generally not problematic.
content.plain_text: Re-performance of the service is the typical remedy for a service warranty failure. While Zebracorp's templates often omit this, specifying it is generally not problematic.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies the standard remedy for service warranties and encourages explicit inclusion in contracts, even if not in templates, to ensure clarity and enforceability.
content.conditions: Service warranty failure.
content.justification: Clarifies the standard remedy and ensures enforceability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should consider specifying re-performance as the remedy for service warranty failures.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to propose re-performance as the remedy for service warranty failures.
content.source_insight: The text states what the remedy 'is typically' and that specifying it 'is generally not problematic'.
content.text: The remedy for failure to meet a service warranty is typically the re-performance of the respective service. Most Zebracorp procurement contract templates do not specify such remedies, but having these remedies specified is generally not problematic.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that whenever the services are of advisory nature, it is generally acceptable to state that ‘no specific business result is warranted or guaranteed’.
content.plain_text: For advisory services, it is generally acceptable to state that no specific business result is warranted or guaranteed.
content.expert_insight: This is a practical concession for advisory services, recognizing that outcomes depend on many factors beyond the service provider's control, and managing expectations appropriately.
content.conditions: Services are of an advisory nature.
content.justification: Outcomes of advisory services depend on many factors beyond the service provider's control.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can accept disclaimers for specific business results for advisory services.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers of advisory services can expect Zebracorp to accept disclaimers for specific business results.
content.source_insight: The text states 'it is generally acceptable to state'.
content.text: Please note that whenever the services are of advisory nature, it is generally acceptable to state that ‘no specific business result is warranted or guaranteed’.

content.verbatim_text: Certain warranties such as in e.g. warranties for certain product attributes, backward or forward compatibility and interoperability are often referred to as non-standard warranties as they go beyond the typical warranties against products defects and non-functionality.
content.plain_text: Non-standard warranties refer to those covering specific product attributes, backward/forward compatibility, and interoperability, distinguishing them from typical defect and non-functionality warranties.
content.expert_insight: This defines a category of warranties that are beyond the basic defect coverage, signaling they may require more specific negotiation and justification.
