content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Certain warranties such as in e.g. warranties for certain product attributes, backward or forward compatibility and interoperability are often referred to as non-standard warranties as they go beyond the typical warranties against products defects and non-functionality.

content.verbatim_text: These non-standard warranties can often be negotiated away, and they can prove mandatory only in cases where such warranties are specifically required by Zebracorp’s end customers, or where we have specific requirements for a particular product or deliverable.
content.plain_text: Non-standard warranties are often negotiable and become mandatory only when required by Zebracorp's end customers or for specific product/deliverable requirements.
content.expert_insight: This provides context on the negotiability of non-standard warranties, indicating that ZEBRACORP should prioritize them based on specific customer or product needs.
content.justification: This describes the negotiability and conditions for mandating non-standard warranties.

content.text: These non-standard warranties can often be negotiated away, and they can prove mandatory only in cases where such warranties are specifically required by Zebracorp’s end customers, or where we have specific requirements for a particular product or deliverable.

content.verbatim_text: It is advisable to speak to a member of the L&C team, or the respective Product Line or Customer Team before agreeing to remove such warranties.
content.plain_text: Before removing non-standard warranties, consult with the L&C team, Product Line, or Customer Team.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a critical internal consultation requirement, ensuring that decisions about removing non-standard warranties are made with full awareness of legal and business implications.
content.conditions: Considering removing non-standard warranties.
content.justification: Ensures that the decision to remove such warranties is made with full awareness of legal and business implications.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp personnel must consult relevant internal teams before agreeing to remove non-standard warranties.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect Zebracorp to internally review requests to remove non-standard warranties.

content.text: It is advisable to speak to a member of the L&C team, or the respective Product Line or Customer Team before agreeing to remove such warranties.

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp may also request “warranties” for non-product matters. For example, we might request that the seller “warrant” that it complies with all applicable laws or that the seller is authorized to execute the agreement.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may seek 'warranties' for non-product issues, such as a seller's compliance with laws or authorization to execute an agreement.
content.expert_insight: This expands the concept of 'warranty' beyond product quality to cover legal and operational assurances, highlighting ZEBRACORP's need for broad contractual protections.
content.justification: This provides examples of non-product 'warranties'.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A

content.text: Zebracorp may also request “warranties” for non-product matters. For example, we might request that the seller “warrant” that it complies with all applicable laws or that the seller is authorized to execute the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Where requested by the seller, we should be able change the word “warrants” to in e.g. “covenants” or “shall ensure”.
content.plain_text: If a seller requests, Zebracorp can change 'warrants' to 'covenants' or 'shall ensure' for non-product matters.
content.expert_insight: This provides flexibility in terminology for non-product assurances, accommodating supplier preferences without compromising the underlying binding commitment.

content.justification: Most jurisdictions do not differentiate significantly, and it maintains a binding commitment.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can agree to alternative wording like 'covenants' or 'shall ensure' for non-product warranties if requested by the seller.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can propose changing 'warrants' to 'covenants' or 'shall ensure' for non-product matters.
content.source_insight: The text states 'we should be able change the word'.
content.text: Where requested by the seller, we should be able change the word “warrants” to in e.g. “covenants” or “shall ensure”.

content.verbatim_text: Most jurisdictions will not make a significant difference between a warranty and such other covenant.
content.plain_text: Most legal jurisdictions do not significantly differentiate between a warranty and other similar covenants.
content.expert_insight: This provides the legal rationale for the previous guideline, confirming that the change in terminology does not typically alter the legal effect of the binding commitment.
content.justification: This provides legal context for the interchangeability of terms.

content.verbatim_text: The key for Zebracorp is that the wording provides a binding commitment on the supplier or the persons representing the supplier.
content.plain_text: For Zebracorp, the essential aspect is that the contract wording creates a binding commitment for the supplier or their representatives.
content.expert_insight: This is a core principle for ZEBRACORP, prioritizing the legal enforceability of a commitment over specific terminology, ensuring that the supplier is held accountable.
content.conditions: Negotiating non-product warranties or covenants.
content.justification: Ensures the supplier is legally bound by the commitment, regardless of specific terminology.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure all contractual language for non-product matters creates a binding commitment.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should understand that Zebracorp prioritizes binding commitments over specific wording for non-product matters.
content.source_insight: The text states 'The key for Zebracorp is'.
content.text: The key for Zebracorp is that the wording provides a binding commitment on the supplier or the persons representing the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: It is customary for a vendor to include a provisions stating that the warranties they have provided in the agreement are exclusive i.e. the only and sole warranties given in respect of the sold deliverables.
content.plain_text: Vendors customarily include clauses specifying that the warranties provided in the agreement are exclusive, meaning they are the only warranties for the deliverables.
content.expert_insight: This describes a standard vendor practice to limit their warranty exposure to only those explicitly stated in the contract, which ZEBRACORP should anticipate.
content.justification: This describes a customary vendor practice.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It is customary for a vendor to include a provisions stating that the warranties they have provided in the agreement are exclusive i.e. the only and sole warranties given in respect of the sold deliverables.

content.verbatim_text: A typical clause would read in e.g. as follows: “The warranties and remedies contained in this [Agreement] are the exclusive warranties and remedies given by the [Seller] and are in lieu of and specifically exclude all other express, statutory and implied warranties, including but not limited to the warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose and non-infringement.“
content.plain_text: A typical exclusive warranty clause states: 'The warranties and remedies contained in this [Agreement] are the exclusive warranties and remedies given by the [Seller] and are in lieu of and specifically exclude all other express, statutory and implied warranties, including but not limited to the warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose and non-infringement.'
content.expert_insight: This provides the exact wording of a common exclusive warranty clause, including the specific implied warranties often disclaimed, which is crucial for contract review.
content.justification: This is a direct example provided in the text.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: A typical clause would read in e.g. as follows: “The warranties and remedies contained in this [Agreement] are the exclusive warranties and remedies given by the [Seller] and are in lieu of and specifically exclude all other express, statutory and implied warranties, including but not limited to the warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose and non-infringement.“

content.verbatim_text: The reason for the vendor to propose this type of language is the need to exclude the implied warranties that the vendor might otherwise have under the applicable legislation.
content.plain_text: Vendors propose exclusive warranty language to exclude implied warranties that would otherwise apply under relevant legislation.
content.expert_insight: This explains the strategic motivation behind exclusive warranty clauses, helping ZEBRACORP understand the supplier's objectives.
content.justification: This explains the vendor's reasoning for proposing such language.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The reason for the vendor to propose this type of language is the need to exclude the implied warranties that the vendor might otherwise have under the applicable legislation.

content.verbatim_text: For instance the United States Uniform Commercial Code provides an implied warranty for merchantability (which means the goods must reasonably conform to an ordinary buyer's expectations) and an implied warranty for fitness for purpose.
content.plain_text: The US Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) includes implied warranties of merchantability (goods meet ordinary buyer expectations) and fitness for purpose.
content.expert_insight: This provides specific legal context for implied warranties, particularly under the UCC, which is important for understanding the default legal position in the absence of explicit contractual terms.
content.justification: This provides specific legal examples of implied warranties.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: For instance the United States Uniform Commercial Code provides an implied warranty for merchantability (which means the goods must reasonably conform to an ordinary buyer's expectations) and an implied warranty for fitness for purpose.

content.verbatim_text: Many other countries have Commercial Codes that provide comprehensive statutory warranties that will apply unless the parties have agreed otherwise in their respective contract.
content.plain_text: Many countries have Commercial Codes with statutory warranties that apply unless explicitly overridden by contract.
content.expert_insight: This broadens the legal context beyond the US, highlighting that implied/statutory warranties are a global consideration in contract law.
content.justification: This provides general information about statutory warranties in other countries.
content.implication_company: N/A

content.text: Many other countries have Commercial Codes that provide comprehensive statutory warranties that will apply unless the parties have agreed otherwise in their respective contract.

content.expert_insight: This indicates ZEBRACORP's willingness to accept the exclusion of implied warranties, provided its explicitly negotiated warranties are sufficient, streamlining contract negotiation.

content.justification: Zebracorp relies exclusively on the warranties stipulated in its contract.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can generally agree to exclude implied and statutory warranties.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can expect Zebracorp to generally accept the exclusion of implied and statutory warranties.
content.source_insight: The text states this is 'generally acceptable for Zebracorp'.
content.text: Excluding these implied and statutory warranties is generally acceptable for Zebracorp.

In these cases, it is not problematic to accept the above type of language that specifically says that all remedies are exclusively defined in the contract.

content.text: Also the remedies, that is, the rights of the buyer to in e.g. a refund or a replacement product when a warranty is breached are often exclusively defined in the purchasing contract. In these cases, it is not problematic to accept the above type of language that specifically says that all remedies are exclusively defined in the contract.

content.verbatim_text: Because of the uncertainty surrounding such implied warranties, any prudent supplier/subcontractor would want to limit its liability to the mutually in writing agreed express warranties only, and disclaim all liability for implied warranties.
content.plain_text: To mitigate uncertainty, a prudent supplier or subcontractor should aim to limit liability solely to mutually agreed-upon express warranties and disclaim all implied warranties.

content.text: These type of all-inclusive warranty disclaimers should be considered for free-of-charge products and services only, and should never be considered when paying market price for a sold product/service.

content.verbatim_text: Only sample products (prototypes and preproduction units) are generally sold without a warranty, with the understanding that they will not be placed into commercial use and are provided free-of-charge.
content.plain_text: Typically, only free-of-charge sample products (prototypes, preproduction units) are sold without warranties, with the explicit understanding they are not for commercial use.
content.expert_insight: This provides context on specific scenarios where 'no warranty' is standard, linking it to the non-commercial nature and free provision of the items.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Only sample products (prototypes and preproduction units) are generally sold without a warranty, with the understanding that they will not be placed into commercial use and are provided free-of-charge.

content.verbatim_text: Open source or other freely available royalty-free software also typically comes with warranty disclaimers only i.e. without any warranties whatsoever.
content.plain_text: Open source and royalty-free software generally come with complete warranty disclaimers, meaning no warranties are provided.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies the common practice for a specific category of software, which is important for ZEBRACORP's procurement strategy in this area.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Open source or other freely available royalty-free software also typically comes with warranty disclaimers only i.e. without any warranties whatsoever.

content.verbatim_text: The purchasing contracts typically provide express warranties on the hardware being free from defects in A. design, B. material and C. workmanship.
content.plain_text: Purchasing contracts usually include express warranties for hardware, covering freedom from defects in design, material, and workmanship.
content.expert_insight: This outlines the standard scope of hardware warranties, providing a baseline for negotiations.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The purchasing contracts typically provide express warranties on the hardware being free from defects in A. design, B. material and C. workmanship.

content.verbatim_text: On top of these warranties, ZEBRACORP generally requires in its procurement contract templates the supplier to warrant that the procured hardware complies with the applicable product specifications and the Zebracorp Quality Requirements, and that the hardware is fit for the purpose for which it was intended.
content.plain_text: ZEBRACORP's procurement contracts typically mandate that suppliers warrant procured hardware complies with product specifications, Zebracorp Quality Requirements, and is fit for its intended purpose.
content.expert_insight: This specifies ZEBRACORP's additional, non-negotiable requirements for hardware warranties, ensuring the products meet both technical and quality standards, as well as functional suitability.
content.conditions: Procurement of hardware by ZEBRACORP.
content.justification: Ensures hardware meets specific quality, technical, and functional needs of ZEBRACORP.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP has strong contractual rights regarding hardware quality and fitness for purpose.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be prepared to warrant compliance with ZEBRACORP's specifications, quality requirements, and fitness for purpose.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: On top of these warranties, ZEBRACORP generally requires in its procurement contract templates the supplier to warrant that the procured hardware complies with the applicable product specifications and the Zebracorp Quality Requirements, and that the hardware is fit for the purpose for which it was intended.

content.verbatim_text: Warranty for defects in material and workmanship is usually non-contentious and generally accepted by the sellers.
content.plain_text: Warranties covering defects in material and workmanship are typically non-controversial and readily accepted by sellers.
content.expert_insight: This indicates common ground in warranty negotiations, making these specific clauses easier to secure.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Warranty for defects in material and workmanship is usually non-contentious and generally accepted by the sellers.

content.verbatim_text: On the other hand warranty for design defects can be controversial and some sellers may seek to exclude it.
content.plain_text: Conversely, warranties for design defects are often contentious, with some sellers attempting to exclude them.
content.expert_insight: This flags a potential area of negotiation difficulty, requiring ZEBRACORP to be prepared to defend its position.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: On the other hand warranty for design defects can be controversial and some sellers may seek to exclude it.

content.verbatim_text: However, in most cases, there is really no justification to exclude warranty for non-functionality that is caused by a design defect. ZEBRACORP does not control the design of the product and it would be unreasonable to pass the risk of design defects over to ZEBRACORP. It would be an untenable position if ZEBRACORP would be unable to return products that break down due to defects in the design work.
content.plain_text: Excluding warranties for design defect-caused non-functionality is generally unjustified, as ZEBRACORP doesn't control product design and shouldn't bear that risk. It would be unacceptable if ZEBRACORP couldn't return products failing due to design flaws.
content.expert_insight: This provides ZEBRACORP with a strong rationale for insisting on design defect warranties, emphasizing the supplier's responsibility for their own design work and the unreasonableness of shifting this risk.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: However, in most cases, there is really no justification to exclude warranty for non-functionality that is caused by a design defect. ZEBRACORP does not control the design of the product and it would be unreasonable to pass the risk of design defects over to ZEBRACORP. It would be an untenable position if ZEBRACORP would be unable to return products that break down due to defects in the design work.

content.verbatim_text: More often than not, the suppliers seek to revise the warranty language to say that the warranty only applies to “material” non-compliance with the specifications and agreed requirements.
content.plain_text: Suppliers frequently attempt to modify warranty language, limiting coverage to only 'material' non-compliance with specifications and agreed requirements.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a common supplier tactic in negotiations, which ZEBRACORP needs to be aware of and prepared to counter.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: More often than not, the suppliers seek to revise the warranty language to say that the warranty only applies to “material” non-compliance with the specifications and agreed requirements.

content.verbatim_text: An example of such qualifier would read in e.g. as follows: “…the [Seller] warrants that the [products] materially comply with the applicable product specifications and quality requirements…”
content.plain_text: An example of a 'material' qualifier is a clause stating that the seller warrants products 'materially comply' with specifications and quality requirements.
content.expert_insight: This provides a direct textual example of the problematic language suppliers might introduce.
content.justification: Illustrates the 'material' non-compliance qualifier.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: An example of such qualifier would read in e.g. as follows: “…the [Seller] warrants that the [products] materially comply with the applicable product specifications and quality requirements…”

content.verbatim_text: These qualifiers are very difficult to accept as it would put an obligation on Zebracorp to prove not only that there is a deviation but that the deviation is material. The seller could potentially use this qualifier to arbitrarily refuse warranty repairs/replacement requests.
content.plain_text: Qualifiers like 'material non-compliance' are hard to accept because they burden Zebracorp with proving both a deviation and its materiality, potentially allowing sellers to arbitrarily deny warranty claims.
content.expert_insight: This is a strong recommendation against accepting 'material' qualifiers due to the increased burden of proof on ZEBRACORP and the risk of arbitrary claim rejections by suppliers.
content.conditions: Supplier proposes 'material' non-compliance qualifier.
content.justification: Shifts burden of proof to ZEBRACORP and allows for arbitrary refusal of warranty claims by supplier.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP would have to expend resources proving materiality of defects, risking denied claims.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers benefit from this qualifier by having a stronger position to deny warranty claims.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: These qualifiers are very difficult to accept as it would put an obligation on Zebracorp to prove not only that there is a deviation but that the deviation is material. The seller could potentially use this qualifier to arbitrarily refuse warranty repairs/replacement requests.

content.verbatim_text: Also, having the seller warrant that the product it sells complies with its own product specifications is generally not viewed as an unreasonable request.
content.plain_text: It is generally considered a reasonable request for a seller to warrant that their product complies with its own specifications.
content.expert_insight: This provides a baseline of reasonableness in negotiations, indicating that this specific warranty is standard and expected.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Also, having the seller warrant that the product it sells complies with its own product specifications is generally not viewed as an unreasonable request.

content.verbatim_text: If we nevertheless cannot negotiate away this qualifier, a compromise can be found by saying in e.g. that “the above product warranty does not apply to any such trivial or minor errors that do not affect the functionality or operation of the product”.
content.plain_text: If unable to remove 'material' qualifiers, a compromise is to state that the warranty excludes trivial or minor errors that do not impact product functionality or operation.
content.expert_insight: This offers a pragmatic compromise for ZEBRACORP, allowing for some flexibility while still protecting against significant defects by focusing on functional impact.
content.conditions: Inability to negotiate away 'material' non-compliance qualifiers.
content.justification: Provides a compromise that protects against significant defects while acknowledging minor, non-functional errors.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP accepts minor, non-functional errors but retains warranty rights for functional issues.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers gain some protection from trivial claims but remain liable for functional defects.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: If we nevertheless cannot negotiate away this qualifier, a compromise can be found by saying in e.g. that “the above product warranty does not apply to any such trivial or minor errors that do not affect the functionality or operation of the product”.

content.verbatim_text: In order to align the hardware warranty to the standard warranty offered to Zebracorp customers, we should request at a minimum 24 months warranty.
content.plain_text: To align with Zebracorp's customer offerings, a minimum 24-month hardware warranty should be requested.
content.expert_insight: This is a clear requirement for ZEBRACORP's procurement, ensuring consistency with its downstream commitments.
content.conditions: Procuring hardware for Zebracorp.
content.justification: Ensures back-to-back warranty coverage with end-customer commitments.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP secures sufficient warranty period to cover its own customer obligations.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must offer at least a 24-month warranty for hardware sold to ZEBRACORP.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In order to align the hardware warranty to the standard warranty offered to Zebracorp customers, we should request at a minimum 24 months warranty.

content.verbatim_text: In direct procurement contracts it is important to extend the warranty period by some months to in e.g. 26-26 months in cases where the warranty kicks in upon delivery to Zebracorp in order to allow sufficient time for the hardware to be installed at the end customer and to be at least provisionally accepted by the end customer.
content.plain_text: In direct procurement, extend hardware warranties to 26-28 months if they start upon delivery to Zebracorp. This ensures enough time for installation and provisional acceptance by the end customer.
content.expert_insight: This is a strategic instruction for ZEBRACORP to account for the operational lead time between receiving hardware and its final acceptance by the end customer, preventing a gap in warranty coverage.
content.conditions: Direct procurement contracts where warranty starts upon delivery to Zebracorp.
content.justification: Allows sufficient time for installation and provisional acceptance by the end customer, aligning with end-customer contract start dates.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP ensures continuous warranty coverage until the end customer's acceptance.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may need to offer longer warranty periods for direct procurement to ZEBRACORP.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In direct procurement contracts it is important to extend the warranty period by some months to in e.g. 26-26 months in cases where the warranty kicks in upon delivery to Zebracorp in order to allow sufficient time for the hardware to be installed at the end customer and to be at least provisionally accepted by the end customer.

content.verbatim_text: This is because in most of our end-customer contracts, the warranties start to run from provisional acceptance or date of delivery to customer sites.
content.plain_text: This extension is necessary because most end-customer contracts initiate warranties from provisional acceptance or delivery to customer sites.
content.expert_insight: This explains the 'why' behind the previous guideline, reinforcing the need for back-to-back coverage.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: This is because in most of our end-customer contracts, the warranties start to run from provisional acceptance or date of delivery to customer sites.

content.verbatim_text: Note also that the warranty periods can vary greatly between different type of products.
content.plain_text: Warranty periods can differ significantly across various product types.
content.expert_insight: This serves as a general reminder that warranty terms are not uniform and require case-by-case consideration.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Note also that the warranty periods can vary greatly between different type of products.

content.verbatim_text: When procuring site materials, certain fixed structures such as in e.g. antenna towers and monopoles may require warranties of up to 10-15 years and such extended warranties are generally seen perfectly standard in that industry.
content.plain_text: For site materials like antenna towers, warranties of 10-15 years are common and standard within the industry.
content.expert_insight: This provides a specific example of extended warranty periods for particular product categories, informing ZEBRACORP's expectations in those sectors.
content.justification: Illustrates variation in warranty periods for specific products.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: When procuring site materials, certain fixed structures such as in e.g. antenna towers and monopoles may require warranties of up to 10-15 years and such extended warranties are generally seen perfectly standard in that industry.

content.verbatim_text: Whilst it is in Zebracorp’s interest to be able, not only to have the defective product repaired or replaced, but also to have the right to seek reimbursement for eventual production line stoppage, the time spent tracing defects, testing and similar costs, most vendors will insist that the sole remedy for a breach of a product warranty should be the repair or replacement of the product.
content.plain_text: While Zebracorp prefers to seek reimbursement for ancillary costs like production stoppage and defect tracing in addition to repair/replacement, most vendors insist that repair or replacement is the sole remedy for a product warranty breach.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a common conflict in warranty negotiations: ZEBRACORP's desire for comprehensive compensation versus the vendor's preference for limited remedies.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Whilst it is in Zebracorp’s interest to be able, not only to have the defective product repaired or replaced, but also to have the right to seek reimbursement for eventual production line stoppage, the time spent tracing defects, testing and similar costs, most vendors will insist that the sole remedy for a breach of a product warranty should be the repair or replacement of the product.

content.verbatim_text: Some of Zebracorp procurement contract templates have specific clauses that will give Zebracorp the right to seek compensation for ancillary costs such as those described above.
content.plain_text: Some of Zebracorp's procurement contract templates include clauses allowing Zebracorp to claim compensation for ancillary costs related to warranty breaches.
content.expert_insight: This indicates that ZEBRACORP has existing mechanisms to address ancillary costs, which can be leveraged in negotiations.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Some of Zebracorp procurement contract templates have specific clauses that will give Zebracorp the right to seek compensation for ancillary costs such as those described above.

content.verbatim_text: “If [Buyer], due to defective [Products], incurs costs, expenses or damages in connection with production stoppage, line down, de-installation or reinstallation of defective products, or in connection with product defect tracing or product testing and/or such other labour costs, [Supplier] shall reimburse [Buyer] any such costs, expenses and damages.”
content.plain_text: An example clause states that if the Buyer incurs costs (e.g., production stoppage, reinstallation, defect tracing, testing, labor) due to defective Products, the Supplier must reimburse the Buyer for these costs.
content.expert_insight: This provides a direct example of a robust clause that ZEBRACORP uses to claim ancillary costs, serving as a template for desired language.
content.justification: Illustrates a clause for ancillary cost reimbursement.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: “If [Buyer], due to defective [Products], incurs costs, expenses or damages in connection with production stoppage, line down, de-installation or reinstallation of defective products, or in connection with product defect tracing or product testing and/or such other labour costs, [Supplier] shall reimburse [Buyer] any such costs, expenses and damages.”

content.verbatim_text: These clauses can be negotiated away under pressure or the list of ancillary costs, for which the seller is liable, can be negotiated and narrowed down.
content.plain_text: Clauses for ancillary costs can be negotiated away or the list of covered costs can be narrowed down under pressure.
content.expert_insight: This indicates that ZEBRACORP acknowledges the negotiability of these clauses, offering flexibility in high-pressure situations.
content.conditions: Under pressure from supplier during negotiations.
content.justification: Allows for flexibility in negotiations to secure other favorable terms.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP may need to compromise on ancillary cost recovery in some deals.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers have a chance to negotiate down or remove ancillary cost clauses.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: These clauses can be negotiated away under pressure or the list of ancillary costs, for which the seller is liable, can be negotiated and narrowed down.

content.verbatim_text: Another option would be to retain the clause and, as a compromise, add an obligation on Zebracorp to mitigate any costs, expenses and damages that Zebracorp would seek from the supplier under the clause.
content.plain_text: As a compromise, Zebracorp can keep ancillary cost clauses but add an obligation for Zebracorp to mitigate any costs, expenses, and damages sought from the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This offers another compromise strategy, balancing ZEBRACORP's right to claim costs with a responsibility to minimize them, which can be more palatable for suppliers.
content.conditions: Seeking a compromise on ancillary cost clauses.
content.justification: Balances ZEBRACORP's right to claim costs with a reasonable obligation to mitigate, making the clause more acceptable to suppliers.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP retains the right to claim ancillary costs but must demonstrate mitigation efforts.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may accept ancillary cost clauses if ZEBRACORP is obligated to mitigate damages.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Another option would be to retain the clause and, as a compromise, add an obligation on Zebracorp to mitigate any costs, expenses and damages that Zebracorp would seek from the supplier under the clause.

content.verbatim_text: However, please note that it is still customary to expect that the vendor pays for the logistics and other transportation costs associated with the delivery of the repaired or replaced equipment as part of its standard warranty obligations.
content.plain_text: It is customary to expect vendors to cover logistics and transportation costs for delivering repaired or replaced equipment as part of their standard warranty obligations.
content.expert_insight: This sets a firm expectation for ZEBRACORP: these specific costs should always be borne by the vendor under warranty, as it's a standard industry practice.
content.conditions: Warranty claim involving repaired or replaced equipment.
content.justification: This is a customary and standard expectation in warranty obligations.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP should not incur logistics costs for repaired/replaced warranty items.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are expected to cover logistics for repaired/replaced equipment under warranty.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: However, please note that it is still customary to expect that the vendor pays for the logistics and other transportation costs associated with the delivery of the repaired or replaced equipment as part of its standard warranty obligations.

content.verbatim_text: In certain cases Zebracorp can agree that it will pay for the shipment of the returned product to vendor but it would be highly unusual for Zebracorp as the customer to pay all logistics costs for warranty returns.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp may agree to pay for returning a defective product to the vendor, but paying all logistics costs for warranty returns as the customer would be highly unusual.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a boundary for ZEBRACORP's flexibility, indicating a willingness to share some costs but drawing a line at bearing the full burden of return logistics.
content.conditions: Negotiating logistics costs for warranty returns.
content.justification: While some compromise is possible, it's not standard for the customer to bear all return logistics costs.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP generally avoids paying all logistics costs for warranty returns.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect to cover most logistics costs for warranty returns, though ZEBRACORP might cover initial shipment to vendor in some cases.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In certain cases Zebracorp can agree that it will pay for the shipment of the returned product to vendor but it would be highly unusual for Zebracorp as the customer to pay all logistics costs for warranty returns.

content.verbatim_text: Sellers will habitually wish to retain the right to choose the appropriate remedy and in most cases it is perfectly acceptable that the seller is provided with the opportunity to honour the warranty by either repairing or replacing the defective product.
content.plain_text: Sellers typically prefer to choose the warranty remedy, and it's generally acceptable for them to have the option to repair or replace defective products.
content.expert_insight: This acknowledges a common vendor preference and indicates ZEBRACORP's willingness to accept this approach, streamlining the resolution process.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Sellers will habitually wish to retain the right to choose the appropriate remedy and in most cases it is perfectly acceptable that the seller is provided with the opportunity to honour the warranty by either repairing or replacing the defective product.

content.verbatim_text: In case the repair or replace of the product is not feasible, the sellers will generally afford Zebracorp right for a refund i.e. a credit of the purchase price of the product.
content.plain_text: If repair or replacement isn't feasible, sellers usually grant Zebracorp a refund or credit for the product's purchase price.
content.expert_insight: This outlines the typical fallback remedy when primary options are unavailable, confirming ZEBRACORP's expectation of a refund in such scenarios.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In case the repair or replace of the product is not feasible, the sellers will generally afford Zebracorp right for a refund i.e. a credit of the purchase price of the product.

content.verbatim_text: In case of refund, the seller may wish to limit the refund to a depreciated value of the product in the event the product cannot be repaired or replaced (e.g. if the product has a six year useful life and it fails after two years, the seller may want to limit the refund to 33% of the purchase price instead of 100%). Such depreciation provisions are not unusual. The numbers can always be negotiated.
content.plain_text: For refunds, sellers may seek to limit the amount to the product's depreciated value if repair/replacement is impossible. Such depreciation clauses are common and negotiable.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a common vendor tactic to reduce refund liability based on product usage, but also emphasizes that these terms are open for negotiation.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In case of refund, the seller may wish to limit the refund to a depreciated value of the product in the event the product cannot be repaired or replaced (e.g. if the product has a six year useful life and it fails after two years, the seller may want to limit the refund to 33% of the purchase price instead of 100%). Such depreciation provisions are not unusual. The numbers can always be negotiated.

content.verbatim_text: Sophisticated vendors will refuse to give Zebracorp an explicit right to require refund because of revenue recognition concerns.
content.plain_text: Sophisticated vendors often refuse to explicitly grant Zebracorp a right to demand a refund, primarily due to revenue recognition accounting concerns.
content.expert_insight: This explains a specific reason for vendor resistance, allowing ZEBRACORP to understand the underlying motivations during negotiations.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Sophisticated vendors will refuse to give Zebracorp an explicit right to require refund because of revenue recognition concerns.

content.verbatim_text: Remaining silent about the refund can often be accepted so long as the agreement contains at a minimum a right for Zebracorp to obtain a repaired or replaced product.
content.plain_text: Accepting silence on refund rights is often acceptable, provided the agreement guarantees Zebracorp the right to a repaired or replaced product.
content.expert_insight: This offers a pragmatic approach for ZEBRACORP, prioritizing the core remedy (repair/replace) and accepting implicit refund rights if explicit ones are problematic for the vendor.
content.conditions: Agreement includes a minimum right for Zebracorp to obtain a repaired or replaced product.
content.justification: Prioritizes the primary remedies of repair or replacement, which are often sufficient.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP may not have an explicit refund right but still has recourse through repair/replacement.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may avoid explicit refund clauses if repair/replacement is guaranteed.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Remaining silent about the refund can often be accepted so long as the agreement contains at a minimum a right for Zebracorp to obtain a repaired or replaced product.

content.verbatim_text: Should the supplier be unable to repair/replace the product, we should be able to require refund even in the absence of an explicit contract provision.
content.plain_text: If a supplier cannot repair or replace a product, Zebracorp should be able to demand a refund, even without an explicit contractual provision.
content.expert_insight: This asserts ZEBRACORP's inherent right to a refund as a last resort, even if not explicitly stated, relying on general principles of contract law or commercial reasonableness.
content.conditions: Supplier is unable to repair or replace the product.
content.justification: It is a fundamental commercial expectation that if a product cannot be remedied, a refund is due.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP should pursue refunds in such cases, regardless of explicit contract language.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers implicitly owe a refund if repair/replacement is impossible, even if not explicitly stated.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Should the supplier be unable to repair/replace the product, we should be able to require refund even in the absence of an explicit contract provision.

content.verbatim_text: Software warranties can be controversial. Most software vendors, notably those based in North America, have a very conservative and reserved approach on software warranties, and are likely to specifically disclaim any warranties that would imply that software will be bug-free, error-free, or that it will run without interruption.
content.plain_text: Software warranties are often controversial, with many North American vendors taking a conservative stance, typically disclaiming warranties implying bug-free, error-free, or uninterrupted software operation.
content.expert_insight: This highlights the inherent challenges in negotiating software warranties, setting expectations for vendor resistance to broad guarantees.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Software warranties can be controversial. Most software vendors, notably those based in North America, have a very conservative and reserved approach on software warranties, and are likely to specifically disclaim any warranties that would imply that software will be bug-free, error-free, or that it will run without interruption.

content.verbatim_text: Many vendors may also seek to disclaim software warranties altogether and instead say that the software comes on “as is” basis without any warranty of any kind.
content.plain_text: Many vendors may try to disclaim all software warranties, offering the software 'as is' without any guarantees.
content.expert_insight: This describes a common vendor position that ZEBRACORP must be prepared to address.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Many vendors may also seek to disclaim software warranties altogether and instead say that the software comes on “as is” basis without any warranty of any kind.

content.verbatim_text: While this may be acceptable for royalty-free software, it is should not be accepted for software that carries a license fee or a price tag.
content.plain_text: Accepting 'as is' software warranties is only appropriate for royalty-free software; it must be rejected for software with a license fee or price tag.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical, non-negotiable stance for ZEBRACORP, distinguishing between free and paid software regarding warranty expectations.
content.conditions: Software carries a license fee or price tag.
content.justification: Paying for software implies an expectation of functionality and quality, which 'as is' disclaimers negate.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP must not accept 'as is' warranties for paid software.

content.verbatim_text: In fact in many cases it may be adequate that the licensor warrants that the software is compliant with its specifications, and that the software materially performs all functions described in the product specifications/product documentation.

content.verbatim_text: In addition to these two warranted items, warranties on software being free from viruses, spyware or other malicious code is often non-contentions and we should seek to include such anti-virus warranty.
content.plain_text: Beyond compliance and functionality, ZEBRACORP should seek to include non-contentious warranties ensuring software is free from viruses, spyware, or other malicious code.

content.text: In addition to these two warranted items, warranties on software being free from viruses, spyware or other malicious code is often non-contentions and we should seek to include such anti-virus warranty.

content.verbatim_text: Note that, unlike with hardware warranties, when it comes to software warranties, it may be perfectly acceptable for the seller to warrant the software only materially meets the specifications. This is because software will inherently have some errors and bugs.

content.expert_insight: This provides important differentiation between hardware and software warranty expectations, recognizing the inherent nature of software development.

content.justification: Software inherently contains errors and bugs, making 'material' compliance a more realistic standard.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP can accept 'material compliance' for software, reducing negotiation friction.

content.text: Note that, unlike with hardware warranties, when it comes to software warranties, it may be perfectly acceptable for the seller to warrant the software only materially meets the specifications. This is because software will inherently have some errors and bugs.

content.verbatim_text: However, it is also possible that we are relying on the software warranty instead of software support, and elect not to purchase software support for the duration of the warranty. It is also possible that the our end customer requires a warranty on software being error-free, in which case we are, for obvious reasons, inclined to look for similar warranty on our software vendor. In these cases, it is important to have a warranty for software being free from errors and to have the licensor commit to resolve any errors within the resolution times that are specified in the support agreement.
content.plain_text: If Zebracorp or its end customer relies on software warranty instead of support, or if the end customer requires error-free software, then an error-free software warranty is crucial. The licensor must commit to resolving errors within specified support agreement times.
content.expert_insight: This outlines specific scenarios where an 'error-free' software warranty becomes a critical requirement for ZEBRACORP, linking it to internal strategy or external customer commitments.
content.conditions: Zebracorp relies on software warranty instead of support, OR end customer requires error-free software.
content.justification: Ensures ZEBRACORP meets its own commitments or manages risk if not purchasing support.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP must secure a strong, error-free warranty and defined resolution times in these specific cases.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must be prepared to offer error-free software warranties with resolution commitments under these conditions.

It is also possible that the our end customer requires a warranty on software being error-free, in which case we are, for obvious reasons, inclined to look for similar warranty on our software vendor. In these cases, it is important to have a warranty for software being free from errors and to have the licensor commit to resolve any errors within the resolution times that are specified in the support agreement.

content.verbatim_text: In order to make the warranty on error-free more palatable for the licensor, it may be worthwhile specifying that the software error correction measures are our sole remedy and the licensor’s sole liability for failure to meet this type of a warranty.

content.justification: Limits licensor's financial exposure, increasing their willingness to provide an error-free warranty.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP accepts error correction as the sole remedy for error-free warranty breaches.
content.implication_supplier: Licensors may be more willing to grant error-free warranties if liability is limited to error correction.

content.text: In order to make the warranty on error-free more palatable for the licensor, it may be worthwhile specifying that the software error correction measures are our sole remedy and the licensor’s sole liability for failure to meet this type of a warranty.

content.verbatim_text: This is because the software vendor will wish to have clear visibility as the eventual consequences of warranting that the software is error-free while knowing full well that the software will have bugs and errors. The vendor is likely to accept giving such warranty only as long as we make it clear that the sole consequence of failing to meet such warranty is that the vendor will attempt to resolve the errors in accordance with the software support agreement.
content.plain_text: Vendors want clear visibility into consequences of 'error-free' warranties, knowing software has bugs. They'll likely accept only if the sole consequence of breach is error resolution per the support agreement.
content.expert_insight: This provides the underlying reasoning for vendors' reluctance and their likely conditions for accepting an 'error-free' warranty, aiding ZEBRACORP in negotiations.

content.text: This is because the software vendor will wish to have clear visibility as the eventual consequences of warranting that the software is error-free while knowing full well that the software will have bugs and errors. The vendor is likely to accept giving such warranty only as long as we make it clear that the sole consequence of failing to meet such warranty is that the vendor will attempt to resolve the errors in accordance with the software support agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Many vendors are keen to propose a warranty that essentially says that the media on which the software is delivered is errorfree. Note that this is not the same as warranting that the software itself is free from errors. This type of warranty only provides that the actual media on which the software is delivered i.e. that the DVD that contained the software is not defective. This type of a warranty on the delivery medium does not provide much added-value to Zebracorp, and it is not a substitute for a proper software warranty, and should not be mistaken for an actual software warranty.
content.plain_text: Many vendors offer warranties only for the software delivery media (e.g., DVD), not the software itself. This provides little value to Zebracorp and should not be confused with or accepted as a proper software warranty.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical warning for ZEBRACORP to identify and reject inadequate 'media-only' warranties, ensuring they secure actual software functionality guarantees.
content.conditions: Vendor proposes a warranty solely for the software delivery media.
content.justification: Such a warranty provides negligible value and does not cover the software's functionality, which is ZEBRACORP's primary concern.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP must reject media-only warranties as insufficient.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers offering media-only warranties should expect rejection from ZEBRACORP.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Many vendors are keen to propose a warranty that essentially says that the media on which the software is delivered is errorfree. Note that this is not the same as warranting that the software itself is free from errors. This type of warranty only provides that the actual media on which the software is delivered i.e. that the DVD that contained the software is not defective. This type of a warranty on the delivery medium does not provide much added-value to Zebracorp, and it is not a substitute for a proper software warranty, and should not be mistaken for an actual software warranty.

The compatibility warranty is however often limited to the current release and the immediately preceding major release only i.e. N-1. This is generally acceptable whenever Zebracorp has adequate visibility to the software release cycle through roadmaps or otherwise, and/or where Zebracorp can somehow control such release cycle.

content.verbatim_text: The typical duration for a software warranty ranges from ninety days to twelve months. Zebracorp standard warranty offering to its end customers typically extends to ninety days. However, it is by no means unusual for us to be committed to software warranties that exceed ninety days. In many countries where we operate it may not be uncommon to see software warranties of up to twelve months, or even longer. Such warranties are fairly prevalent in particular in the European countries as opposed to the US market where the software warranties are as a rule limited to ninety days or six months.
content.plain_text: Software warranties typically last 90 days to 12 months. While Zebracorp's standard customer offering is 90 days, longer warranties are common, especially in Europe (up to 12+ months), contrasting with the US market's usual 90-day or 6-month limits.
content.expert_insight: This provides a comprehensive overview of typical software warranty durations, highlighting regional differences and ZEBRACORP's internal standards versus market realities.
