content.verbatim_text: The same applies to requests to exclude failures caused by operation of the products beyond their capabilities. The operating parameters should be spelled out in the product specification, and should we, or our end customer, fail to observe those, then and only then it is reasonable that the supplier of the product is excused from its warranty obligations.
content.plain_text: Similarly, exclusions for operating products beyond their capabilities are only reasonable if operating parameters are clearly defined in product specifications, and Zebracorp or its customer fails to observe them.
content.expert_insight: This reinforces the principle of objective measurability, requiring clear documentation of operating parameters before such exclusions can be deemed reasonable.
content.conditions: Supplier requests exclusion for operation beyond capabilities.
content.justification: Supplier's excuse from warranty obligations is only reasonable if operating parameters are clearly defined and violated.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP ensures clear product specifications are in place before accepting such exclusions.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must clearly define operating parameters in product specifications to justify this exclusion.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The same applies to requests to exclude failures caused by operation of the products beyond their capabilities. The operating parameters should be spelled out in the product specification, and should we, or our end customer, fail to observe those, then and only then it is reasonable that the supplier of the product is excused from its warranty obligations.

content.verbatim_text: Excluding supplier’s warranty to use of product in combination with other products is not acceptable as such. We do use our suppliers’ products in conjunction with our own or third party products and equipment. If we were to agree to this exclusion, we should specify that the combination itself must cause the failure in the product, and the combination must not have been known to the supplier or recommended or otherwise permitted by the supplier.
content.plain_text: Excluding warranty for product use in combination with other products is unacceptable. Zebracorp uses supplier products with its own or third-party equipment. If accepted, it must be specified that the combination itself solely caused the failure and was unknown, unrecommended, or unpermitted by the supplier.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical stance for ZEBRACORP, recognizing its operational reality of integrating various products. It provides a strong counter-negotiation position to prevent suppliers from broadly disclaiming liability for integrated systems.
content.conditions: Supplier proposes exclusion for use of product in combination with other products.
content.justification: ZEBRACORP routinely uses supplier products in integrated systems; a broad exclusion would negate warranty for common use cases. Conditions ensure the supplier is only excused if the combination was truly unanticipated and causative of failure.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP protects its ability to integrate products without voiding warranties.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must accept liability for their products in combination unless specific, unknown, and unapproved combinations directly cause failure.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Excluding supplier’s warranty to use of product in combination with other products is not acceptable as such. We do use our suppliers’ products in conjunction with our own or third party products and equipment. If we were to agree to this exclusion, we should specify that the combination itself must cause the failure in the product, and the combination must not have been known to the supplier or recommended or otherwise permitted by the supplier.

content.verbatim_text: The lack of proper maintenance can also be difficult to measure objectively. When agreeing to such exclusion we should verify how proper maintenance is specified in the product specification and product documentation, and whether such maintenance recommendations are reasonable taken into account the nature and planned use of the products/equipment.
content.plain_text: Lack of proper maintenance is hard to measure objectively. If accepting this exclusion, verify how 'proper maintenance' is defined in product specifications/documentation and if recommendations are reasonable for the product's nature and intended use.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes the need for objective criteria for 'proper maintenance' exclusions, requiring ZEBRACORP to scrutinize documentation and reasonableness to prevent arbitrary warranty denials.
content.conditions: Supplier proposes exclusion for lack of proper maintenance.
content.justification: Ensures 'proper maintenance' is objectively defined and reasonable, preventing arbitrary denial of warranty claims.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP ensures maintenance requirements are clear and achievable.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must provide clear, reasonable, and documented maintenance specifications to justify this exclusion.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The lack of proper maintenance can also be difficult to measure objectively. When agreeing to such exclusion we should verify how proper maintenance is specified in the product specification and product documentation, and whether such maintenance recommendations are reasonable taken into account the nature and planned use of the products/equipment.

content.verbatim_text: Improper installation can be usually accepted as a warranty exclusion provided that the installation is done performed by the supplier or any third party authorized by it.
content.plain_text: Improper installation can generally be accepted as a warranty exclusion, provided the installation was performed by the supplier or an authorized third party.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies an acceptable condition for an 'improper installation' exclusion, shifting responsibility to the installer (supplier or its authorized agent) rather than ZEBRACORP.
content.conditions: Installation performed by supplier or supplier-authorized third party.
content.justification: Supplier or its authorized party is responsible for correct installation.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP accepts this exclusion only if the supplier controlled the installation process.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are excused from warranty for improper installation if they or their authorized party performed it.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Improper installation can be usually accepted as a warranty exclusion provided that the installation is done performed by the supplier or any third party authorized by it.

content.verbatim_text: In each of the above cases, we should specify that the misuse, unauthorized combination etc. was the actual cause of the product failing to meet the warranty.
content.plain_text: For any of the aforementioned exclusions, it must be specified that the excluded event (e.g., misuse, unauthorized combination) was the actual cause of the product's warranty failure.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial overarching requirement for all exclusions, placing the burden on the supplier to prove direct causation, protecting ZEBRACORP from arbitrary denials.
content.conditions: Applying any of the listed warranty exclusions.
content.justification: Ensures that the excluded event directly caused the failure, preventing arbitrary denial of warranty claims.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP requires clear proof of causation for any exclusion to apply.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must demonstrate that an excluded event was the direct cause of the product's failure.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In each of the above cases, we should specify that the misuse, unauthorized combination etc. was the actual cause of the product failing to meet the warranty.

content.verbatim_text: Repair by others should not automatically void a warranty. Zebracorp or our customers may routinely use third party repair shops or elect to do self-maintenance.
content.plain_text: Repair by unauthorized parties should not automatically void a warranty, as Zebracorp and its customers routinely use third-party repair or perform self-maintenance.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical stance for ZEBRACORP, protecting its operational flexibility and that of its customers, preventing suppliers from broadly voiding warranties based on common maintenance practices.
content.conditions: Supplier proposes exclusion for repair by others.
content.justification: ZEBRACORP and its customers routinely use third-party repair or self-maintenance, and such actions should not automatically void a warranty unless they directly caused the defect.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP maintains flexibility in product maintenance without voiding warranties.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers cannot automatically void warranties if third parties perform repairs; they must prove causation.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Repair by others should not automatically void a warranty. Zebracorp or our customers may routinely use third party repair shops or elect to do self-maintenance.

content.verbatim_text: In addition, some vendors seek to exclude warranty in case Zebracorp’s tests have failed to detect a defect. This type of exclusion should be generally rejected. Zebracorp does not test the product against any and all requirement specification requirements and even if we did, not all the faults appear in the testing but only after a while in use. The very idea with warranty is to provide the purchasing party with the right to return products that experience defects after their installation and initial testing.
content.plain_text: Exclusions for defects not detected by Zebracorp's tests should be rejected. Zebracorp doesn't test against all requirements, and some faults only appear after use. Warranties exist to allow purchasers to return products with post-installation/testing defects.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical rejection of a vendor tactic, affirming the fundamental purpose of a warranty: to cover defects that manifest after initial checks and during actual use, not to shift the burden of exhaustive testing to the buyer.
content.conditions: Vendor seeks to exclude warranty for defects not detected by Zebracorp's tests.
content.justification: ZEBRACORP's testing is not exhaustive, and warranties are intended to cover defects that emerge post-installation and initial testing.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP retains warranty rights for defects discovered after its own testing.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers cannot use ZEBRACORP's testing limitations as a basis for warranty exclusion.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In addition, some vendors seek to exclude warranty in case Zebracorp’s tests have failed to detect a defect. This type of exclusion should be generally rejected. Zebracorp does not test the product against any and all requirement specification requirements and even if we did, not all the faults appear in the testing but only after a while in use. The very idea with warranty is to provide the purchasing party with the right to return products that experience defects after their installation and initial testing.

content.verbatim_text: Services warranties i.e. warranties in relation to the performance of service have often more limited practical relevance as compared to product warranties. This is predominantly due to the fact that most services are in any event subject to acceptance, while ongoing services such as in e.g. maintenance and support are subject to service level agreements and KPIs.
content.plain_text: Service warranties often have less practical relevance than product warranties because most services are subject to acceptance, and ongoing services (like maintenance/support) are governed by SLAs and KPIs.
content.expert_insight: This provides context on the reduced importance of standalone service warranties, explaining that other contractual mechanisms (acceptance, SLAs) often cover service quality.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Services warranties i.e. warranties in relation to the performance of service have often more limited practical relevance as compared to product warranties. This is predominantly due to the fact that most services are in any event subject to acceptance, while ongoing services such as in e.g. maintenance and support are subject to service level agreements and KPIs.

content.verbatim_text: The service warranty that provides that the services are rendered in professional and skilful manner is a minimum requirement and should be non-contentious.
content.plain_text: A service warranty guaranteeing professional and skillful service delivery is a minimum, non-contentious requirement.
content.expert_insight: This sets a baseline for service warranties, indicating that a professional standard of care is a fundamental and expected guarantee.
content.conditions: Procuring services.
content.justification: Professional and skillful service is a fundamental expectation for any service provision.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP should always secure this minimum service warranty.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect to provide a warranty for professional and skillful service.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The service warranty that provides that the services are rendered in professional and skilful manner is a minimum requirement and should be non-contentious.

content.verbatim_text: In contrast to a product warranty, it is not uncommon to have a service warranty with no defined warranty period.
content.plain_text: Unlike product warranties, service warranties often lack a defined warranty period.
content.expert_insight: This highlights a key difference between product and service warranties, informing ZEBRACORP's expectations for contract drafting.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In contrast to a product warranty, it is not uncommon to have a service warranty with no defined warranty period.

content.verbatim_text: Whenever a specific warranty period is defined, the warranty should start to run from the date of acceptance.
content.plain_text: If a service warranty period is defined, it should commence from the date of acceptance.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a preferred start date for service warranties, aligning with the point when service quality is formally acknowledged.
content.conditions: A specific warranty period is defined for services.
content.justification: Ties the warranty period to the formal acknowledgment of service completion and quality.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP ensures service warranty starts after acceptance, giving time for verification.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should expect service warranties to start from acceptance if a period is defined.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Whenever a specific warranty period is defined, the warranty should start to run from the date of acceptance.

content.verbatim_text: The duration of the warranty period should be sufficient to enable us to verify the results of the service and to have any deficiencies rectified.
content.plain_text: The service warranty duration must be long enough for Zebracorp to verify service results and rectify any deficiencies.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical requirement for ZEBRACORP, ensuring that the warranty period is functionally adequate for its needs, not just an arbitrary number.
content.conditions: Defining a warranty period for services.
content.justification: Ensures ZEBRACORP has adequate time to assess service quality and demand rectification of defects.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP must negotiate service warranty durations based on its verification needs.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers must offer service warranty durations that allow for customer verification and defect rectification.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The duration of the warranty period should be sufficient to enable us to verify the results of the service and to have any deficiencies rectified.

content.verbatim_text: The time frames used in our contract templates are examples only and should be modified on case-by-case basis.
content.plain_text: Contract template timeframes are examples and should be adjusted on a case-by-case basis.
content.expert_insight: This emphasizes flexibility, indicating that standard templates are not rigid and require adaptation to specific circumstances.
content.conditions: Using contract templates for service warranties.
content.justification: Service requirements and verification times vary widely, necessitating case-by-case adjustments.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP should not rigidly apply template timeframes but adapt them.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The time frames used in our contract templates are examples only and should be modified on case-by-case basis.

content.verbatim_text: The remedy for failure to meet a service warranty is typically the re-performance of the respective service.
content.plain_text: The usual remedy for a service warranty failure is the re-performance of the service.
content.expert_insight: This identifies the standard remedy for service warranty breaches, which is logical given the nature of services.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The remedy for failure to meet a service warranty is typically the re-performance of the respective service.

content.verbatim_text: Most Zebracorp procurement contract templates do not specify such remedies, but having these remedies specified is generally not problematic.
content.plain_text: Most Zebracorp templates don't specify service warranty remedies, but including them is generally acceptable.
content.expert_insight: This provides internal guidance that while not standard in templates, explicitly defining remedies for service warranties is acceptable and can add clarity.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Most Zebracorp procurement contract templates do not specify such remedies, but having these remedies specified is generally not problematic.

content.verbatim_text: Please note that whenever the services are of advisory nature, it is generally acceptable to state that ‘no specific business result is warranted or guaranteed’.
content.plain_text: For advisory services, it's generally acceptable to state that 'no specific business result is warranted or guaranteed.'
content.expert_insight: This provides important flexibility for ZEBRACORP when procuring advisory services, acknowledging that outcomes are not always guaranteed in such contexts.
content.conditions: Services are of an advisory nature.
content.justification: Advisory services provide guidance, not guaranteed outcomes, making it unreasonable to warrant specific business results.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP can accept this disclaimer for advisory services.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers of advisory services can reasonably expect to include this disclaimer.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Please note that whenever the services are of advisory nature, it is generally acceptable to state that ‘no specific business result is warranted or guaranteed’.

content.verbatim_text: Certain warranties such as in e.g. warranties for certain product attributes, backward or forward compatibility and interoperability are often referred to as non-standard warranties as they go beyond the typical warranties against products defects and non-functionality.
content.plain_text: Non-standard warranties refer to guarantees for specific product attributes like backward/forward compatibility and interoperability, exceeding typical defect and non-functionality warranties.
content.expert_insight: This defines a category of warranties that are more specialized and often require specific negotiation.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Certain warranties such as in e.g. warranties for certain product attributes, backward or forward compatibility and interoperability are often referred to as non-standard warranties as they go beyond the typical warranties against products defects and non-functionality.

content.verbatim_text: These non-standard warranties can often be negotiated away, and they can prove mandatory only in cases where such warranties are specifically required by Zebracorp’s end customers, or where we have specific requirements for a particular product or deliverable.
content.plain_text: Non-standard warranties are often negotiable and only mandatory if explicitly required by Zebracorp's end customers or for specific product/deliverable requirements.
content.expert_insight: This provides guidance on the negotiability of non-standard warranties, setting conditions under which they become mandatory for ZEBRACORP.
content.conditions: Non-standard warranties are not explicitly required by end customers or for specific product/deliverable requirements.
content.justification: These warranties go beyond typical defect coverage and may not always be necessary.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP has flexibility to negotiate away non-standard warranties unless critical.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may be able to negotiate away non-standard warranties from ZEBRACORP.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: These non-standard warranties can often be negotiated away, and they can prove mandatory only in cases where such warranties are specifically required by Zebracorp’s end customers, or where we have specific requirements for a particular product or deliverable.

content.verbatim_text: It is advisable to speak to a member of the L&C team, or the respective Product Line or Customer Team before agreeing to remove such warranties.
content.plain_text: Consult with the L&C team, Product Line, or Customer Team before agreeing to remove non-standard warranties.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical internal instruction for ZEBRACORP, ensuring that decisions about non-standard warranties are made with appropriate expert consultation.
content.conditions: Considering removing non-standard warranties.
content.justification: Ensures that the decision to remove non-standard warranties is informed by legal, product, and customer-specific expertise.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP ensures proper internal alignment and risk assessment for warranty decisions.
content.implication_supplier: N/A

content.verbatim_text: Zebracorp may also request “warranties” for non-product matters. For example, we might request that the seller “warrant” that it complies with all applicable laws or that the seller is authorized to execute the agreement.

content.expert_insight: This expands the scope of 'warranties' beyond product-specific issues to cover fundamental legal and contractual assurances.

content.text: Zebracorp may also request “warranties” for non-product matters. For example, we might request that the seller “warrant” that it complies with all applicable laws or that the seller is authorized to execute the agreement.

content.verbatim_text: Where requested by the seller, we should be able change the word “warrants” to in e.g. “covenants” or “shall ensure”.
content.plain_text: If a seller requests, Zebracorp can change 'warrants' to 'covenants' or 'shall ensure'.

content.justification: Most jurisdictions consider 'warrants', 'covenants', or 'shall ensure' to have similar binding effect.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP can accommodate this request without losing legal protection.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers may request this change for internal or legal preference.

content.text: Where requested by the seller, we should be able change the word “warrants” to in e.g. “covenants” or “shall ensure”.

content.verbatim_text: Most jurisdictions will not make a significant difference between a warranty and such other covenant.
content.plain_text: Legally, most jurisdictions do not differentiate significantly between a warranty and other similar covenants.
content.expert_insight: This provides the legal justification for the previous guideline, confirming that the linguistic change does not alter the binding nature.

content.verbatim_text: The key for Zebracorp is that the wording provides a binding commitment on the supplier or the persons representing the supplier.
content.plain_text: For Zebracorp, the essential aspect is that the chosen wording creates a binding commitment for the supplier or their representatives.
content.expert_insight: This clarifies ZEBRACORP's core concern: ensuring a legally enforceable obligation, regardless of the specific term used.

content.verbatim_text: It is customary for a vendor to include a provisions stating that the warranties they have provided in the agreement are exclusive i.e. the only and sole warranties given in respect of the sold deliverables.
content.plain_text: Vendors customarily include clauses stating that the warranties provided in the agreement are exclusive, meaning they are the only warranties for the deliverables.
content.expert_insight: This describes a common vendor practice to limit their warranty exposure to explicitly stated terms.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It is customary for a vendor to include a provisions stating that the warranties they have provided in the agreement are exclusive i.e. the only and sole warranties given in respect of the sold deliverables.

content.verbatim_text: A typical clause would read in e.g. as follows: “The warranties and remedies contained in this [Agreement] are the exclusive warranties and remedies given by the [Seller] and are in lieu of and specifically exclude all other express, statutory and implied warranties, including but not limited to the warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose and non-infringement.“
content.plain_text: A typical exclusive warranty clause states that the agreement's warranties and remedies are the seller's sole ones, excluding all other express, statutory, and implied warranties (e.g., merchantability, fitness for purpose, non-infringement).
content.expert_insight: This provides a direct example of a comprehensive warranty disclaimer clause, which ZEBRACORP will encounter in negotiations.
content.justification: Illustrates a typical warranty disclaimer clause.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: A typical clause would read in e.g. as follows: “The warranties and remedies contained in this [Agreement] are the exclusive warranties and remedies given by the [Seller] and are in lieu of and specifically exclude all other express, statutory and implied warranties, including but not limited to the warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose and non-infringement.“

content.verbatim_text: The reason for the vendor to propose this type of language is the need to exclude the implied warranties that the vendor might otherwise have under the applicable legislation.
content.plain_text: Vendors propose this language to exclude implied warranties that would otherwise apply under relevant legislation.
content.expert_insight: This explains the vendor's motivation for using such clauses, which is to limit their legal exposure to unstated obligations.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The reason for the vendor to propose this type of language is the need to exclude the implied warranties that the vendor might otherwise have under the applicable legislation.

content.verbatim_text: For instance the United States Uniform Commercial Code provides an implied warranty for merchantability (which means the goods must reasonably conform to an ordinary buyer's expectations) and an implied warranty for fitness for purpose. Many other countries have Commercial Codes that provide comprehensive statutory warranties that will apply unless the parties have agreed otherwise in their respective contract.
content.plain_text: The US Uniform Commercial Code includes implied warranties for merchantability (goods meet ordinary buyer expectations) and fitness for purpose. Many countries have similar statutory warranties that apply unless contracts state otherwise.
content.expert_insight: This provides concrete examples of implied warranties from the UCC and notes their prevalence in other jurisdictions, underscoring why vendors seek to disclaim them.
content.justification: Illustrates examples of implied warranties.
content.implication_company: N/A
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: For instance the United States Uniform Commercial Code provides an implied warranty for merchantability (which means the goods must reasonably conform to an ordinary buyer's expectations) and an implied warranty for fitness for purpose. Many other countries have Commercial Codes that provide comprehensive statutory warranties that will apply unless the parties have agreed otherwise in their respective contract.

content.verbatim_text: Excluding these implied and statutory warranties is generally acceptable for Zebracorp.
content.plain_text: Excluding implied and statutory warranties is generally acceptable for Zebracorp.
content.expert_insight: This provides a key stance for ZEBRACORP, indicating that it is typically willing to accept disclaimers of implied warranties, provided its explicitly negotiated warranties are robust.

content.justification: ZEBRACORP relies exclusively on warranties stipulated in its contracts.
content.implication_company: ZEBRACORP can agree to exclude implied/statutory warranties without major concern.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can expect ZEBRACORP to generally accept disclaimers of implied/statutory warranties.

content.text: Excluding these implied and statutory warranties is generally acceptable for Zebracorp.

content.verbatim_text: This is because we will be relying exclusively on the warranties that we stipulated in our contract.
content.plain_text: This is because Zebracorp will rely solely on the warranties explicitly defined in its contract.
content.expert_insight: This provides the rationale for accepting implied warranty disclaimers: ZEBRACORP's confidence in its own negotiated express warranties.

content.text: This is because we will be relying exclusively on the warranties that we stipulated in our contract.

content.verbatim_text: Also the remedies, that is, the rights of the buyer to in e.g. a refund or a replacement product when a warranty is breached are often exclusively defined in the purchasing contract. In these cases, it is not problematic to accept the above type of language that specifically says that all remedies are exclusively defined in the contract.

content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can limit their remedy obligations by clearly defining them as exclusive in the contract.

content.text: Also the remedies, that is, the rights of the buyer to in e.g. a refund or a replacement product when a warranty is breached are often exclusively defined in the purchasing contract. In these cases, it is not problematic to accept the above type of language that specifically says that all remedies are exclusively defined in the contract.
